149860706.review:
First impression: 
cute, nice graphics, slow-pace story, almost enjoyable but...
I have lag every time dialogue box appear. The text is slowly and harshly showing. I also notice my cursor is lagging while the box appear.

After digging on the discussion, it seems that I need to use alternative build. I'll update later.

Update for almost 2 hours:
The alternative build is pretty much the solution. No further lag appear.

Full review:
Finding Paradise is a wholesome life journey. We observe a life journey in a man's memory as third party, the doctors. The journey is fully supported by sound effects that bring you virtually inside the event. Some instrumental are also integrated with the story. In addition to the journey, which may bring you vulnerable, there are also comic aspects which I enjoyed.

The mechanics are mostly find items and solve a match 3 puzzle in a series of events. The items can be found by exploring the events. The match 3 puzzle is also easy to solve. The mechanics are not too challenging for enjoying the journey.

I found a lot of unexpected experience. Definitely not flat, but I'm not going to spoil other than that. 

The only disappointment is the lag in the original version. The alternative build is a solid solution for my whole game experience. The only downside is that you cannot finish the achievement. Though, the achievement can be obtained by change to the original and load the last auto-save. It took me around 20 minutes.

A life journey. Comic balanced. Great soundtrack. Puzzle. Unexpected experience.

148655261.review:
[h1][b] TLDR: Freebird Games strikes gold again. What an absolute superb emotional journey. [/b] [/h1]

[h1][b] Gameplay – [2/10] [/b] [/h1]
The gameplay for Freebird games has never been their defining area. In Finding Paradise, the gameplay consists of (excruciatingly slow) walking and some small puzzles. There’s not much else to say here as its mostly a visual novel with some light gameplay. 

[h1] [b] Graphics – [2/10] [/b] [/h1]
Pixel graphics. FP makes it work, but I’d much prefer more modernized 2d if possible. Really nothing noteworthy here. 

[h1] [b] Audio – [10/10] [/b] [/h1]
Music is a core part of the story, and as such, the music in FP hits so hard. It’s very rare to have music invoke such strong emotions in a game for me, but this is 2 of 2 for Freebird Games, I’m not ashamed enough to admit that I definitely teared up when the score hit. 

[h1] [b] Content – [9/10] [/b] [/h1]
What a delightful adventure through the life of a dying man. This game and its characters are written so well. The humor is on point, the story is so meaningful. An overall joyous experience. 
I decided to take a point off due to two main reasons: 
-	A tiny bit of a slog getting to the peak. 
-	Once at the peak, [spoiler] the story descends into ridiculousness for a solid ~30 minutes. [/spoiler]

[h1] [b] Replay Factor – [1/10] [/b] [/h1]
Once you experience the story, the only point to replay is perhaps to notice certain scenes in a different light. There is only a single achievement for completing the game, so, similar to a movie, not a huge incentive to play it again as the playthrough will be the same. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [8/10] [/b] [/h1]
While not perfect, Freebird delivers another solid entry to their catalog. If you can overlook poor graphics, janky controls/movement, and no replay value, then FP is a must-have journey to partake. I cannot wait to check out Imposter Factory. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1] YES. [/h1] Both To the Moon and Finding Paradise are absolute gems that you should definitely pick up as long as you understand what you are getting into. This is a slower type of text-focused game so you need enter with the right mindset. Like curling up under the blanked on a cold, rainy day with a book and hot coco, Finding Paradise should be experienced in a similar mannerism.

147826640.review:
If you've played 'To the Moon', then you've definitely gotta play this one too! I would recommend playing 'To the Moon' first though if you're just now starting out new. 

Anyway, back to this 'Finding Paradise' game, it has the same mechanisms of gameplay [i](find the orbs to smash the protection of a memory, and then prepare that memory via somewhat basic puzzles and then activate it to get to the next stage)[/i]. I promise the repetitive orbs/puzzles are worth it as you get towards the end - warning though, you [i]will[/i] tear up and may need tissues for your leaky eyes. The controls are pretty easy, it's just the arrows and spacebar needed really, but also 'ASWD' for controlling directions in the mini shooter/fighting games. There's quite a lot of dialogue/reading to get through, but that's not surprising for a bittersweet game like this.

Overall, I enjoyed playing this; it was quite captivating, and emotional, and it shows that you can do so much in your short space of life, or during the time that you have left. It's definitely one of those heavy life-lesson types with a mix of comedy [i](thanks to Dr. Watts witty personality)[/i]!

I wanted to also say that this game teaches you about love, happiness, loss/grief, childhood, perhaps amnesia or hallucinations, family, the reality of life, and more importantly.... the following - it's okay to have an imaginary friend no matter how old you are, it's okay to have some regrets in life and to learn from them, and it's okay to let some things go even if we don't want to just yet; they may or may not be holding us back. And sometimes what we thought wasn't going to work out, somehow ends up working out in the long run for whatever miraculous strange reason.

P.S. Don't close the game once the credit ends, there is still a bit more to be watched. I do hope y'all enjoy this game as much as I did!

146879502.review:
[h1] Two Steps Forward, One Step Back [/h1]

To The Moon is one of my favorite narrative driven experiences ever, so I was super excited to finally getting around to playing Finding Paradise, and it did not disappoint... mostly. The story follows the same premise as To The Moon, you play as 2 doctors who are able to grant a dying patients last final wish by going back through their memories and changing the course of their life in order to help them fulfill said wish. While the premise is the same between the two games, the narrative choices are very different. Without going into spoilers, Finding Paradise plays out very different alternatively and I think the game is better off because of this. It helps to separate it from its predecessor. Finding Paradise innovates not only thematically but in its gameplay as well. It does a couple things differently though the core gameplay is very much the same. There are a couple extra little gimmicks here and there that added to the experience. So far so good, right? That's what I was thinking to myself as well while playing until I got about 80% through the game and was met with perhaps the biggest 180 in my enjoyment of a game ever. Without going into spoilers, there is an event that happens that completely sucks you out of the games story right when it's really getting going and what should be an emotional, heartfelt moment turned into 40 minutes of being forced to do awful minigames, and suffer through a complete tonal shift in the games narrative. It turned an 8 or 9/10 game into maybe a 6/10 game for me, it was that jarring and confusing. While I appreciate what the developers tried to do with it, and what they were going for, it really did not work for me. In fact, I went back to watch a playthrough of the game on YouTube and just skipped this portion of the game entirely and it made the story SIGNIFICANTLY better in my opinion. I feel like an extra 5 minutes of dialogue instead of this section would have drastically improved the game. That really is my only real negative about the game, and I still think the game is worth checking out, hence my recommended rating. The themes in the game are handled brilliantly and the soundtrack and story are beautiful. For more game reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]

146422625.review:
[i]Finding Paradise[/i] follows [i]To the Moon[/i], its [i]Sigmund Corp[/i] minisodes, and [i]A Bird Story[/i] in an emotional and rich narrative about childhood, lifelong friendships and relationships, and regrets. Like the first game, it ponders some philosophical and ethical questions about memory, privacy, and truth. Also like the first game, it's an excellent experience.

Mechanically, [i]Finding Paradise[/i] operates similarly to [i]To the Moon[/i]. The general mechanics of memory traversal are the same, with slightly more interesting puzzle minigames; the most interesting part is the discovery process the game guides you through as the player. I appreciated that it didn't block me from progressing in the story with annoying tasks, but also gave me enough to do that I felt some agency throughout: it's a very fluid playthrough. The dialogue, including both its humor and its melancholy, is wonderful and the character emotes are expressive for such a pixelated visual appearance. Audio cues are gracefully integrated into the gameplay, and the soundtrack is likewise fitting and impressive. The level design is strong, keeping the player engaged with a good mix of linearity and backtracking.

I really enjoyed how the game leaned into the humor of one of its characters in particular in the hilarious "combat" scenes (if you can call it that). The narrative cleverly separates the player characters in ways that lead to interesting and fun gameplay, as well as a sense of mystery and urgency. It also keeps the door open for an interesting follow-up game!

Performance was fine and I experienced zero bugs.

Overall, I was pleased with [i]Finding Paradise[/i]. The writing and art direction are wonderful and the gameplay is fun. It's short and sweet, just like its predecessor. I recommend that you play it after the original and its minisodes/follow-ups.

145887833.review:
I just have to say that this developer became one of my IMMEDIATE favorites. The price tag is well justified and I would encourage anyone who likes a great story to jump on this one - and the others (To The Moon, A Bird Story, and Imposter Factory) IMMEDIATELY. This is a series you NEED in your library.

The thing that makes these titles so special is the fact that they're very thoughtful and have complicated storylines, and they run the gamut of content - from light and funny, to dark and serious, to hopeful, heart-broken, upset, happy, and everything in between. This series is one of those that when you start one of the games, you just won't be able to stop until it's finished, and each one has a lot of content/story. Once you start playing, you'll be gripped by it and just HAVE to know how things turn out.. and you'll probably sit there playing until it's done. AMAZING, AMAZING stories.

Basic concept (which, I don't think this will be a spoiler, but I'll hide it anyway): [spoiler] Ever had something you know you're going to regret on your deathbed? Maybe you wish you had done this thing, or made that choice. Now your life is over, and you're regretting how things turned out. What if there was a way to truly believe you HAD done that thing or made that choice? The company Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene work at does just that - on your deathbed, they burrow into your memories, find out what makes you tick, and implant a series of new memories into your head - overwriting the old memories - so that as you pass away, you do so happy with the way things turn out.[/spoiler]

The great thing about each story is diving into it, figuring out what makes each character tick, finding out all about them... and it's told in such an amazing way. I can't tell you enough how fantastic this developer is at telling stories.

My recommendation is to play them in order. While each episode is a "self-contained" episode, it really benefits the player to play them in order. Kinda like how if you watch different episodes of your favorite TV show... sure, each show might be a self-contained story, but you don't get the full context unless you watch them in order.

To The Moon
Finding Paradise
A Bird Story
Imposter Factory

Some folks might disagree and say A Bird Story should come before Finding Paradise, since it sorta comes chronologically before FP... But one of the things that makes each story great is "getting to know" the people involved... and I feel like "A Bird Story" is better viewed as the "deleted scenes" of a movie, rather than as a prequel. If you watch the deleted scenes on a DVD first, maybe it won't "spoil" the movie, but it just doesn't feel right. Play FP first, and then dive a little deeper with ABS.

Get all 4 of these immediately. This is one of the few storyline games that got me a little choked up. I absolutely LOVE the characters and every bit of these stories was phenomenal. I couldn't possibly recommend them any more. They are well worth the full price. I had... SO much fun, and I am ANXIOUSLY awaiting the next chapters from this developer. STUNNING story. Easy gameplay. VERY... very moving.

This is actually the THIRD game in a series, starting with 'To the Moon', and continuing with 'A Bird Story'. 

This continues the story of the two Scientists, Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosaline from To the Moon, but this time the memories you are traversing are of the main character from 'A Bird Story' at the end of his life. 

I don't want to say much more than that, but this is a very well done game, other than the save screen you can't  even tell it was done in RPGMaker. 

This game actually feels more like a point and click adventure game than an RPG anyway, with its ability to use the mouse to interact with anything, and highlighting over interactable objects shows you if they can be interacted with.

144195349.review: It's taken me roughly 10 years to finally play through this episode of the To The Moon series, and I fully expected it to not hit as hard as those first two games did years ago. But having gone through my own elderly mother's death, and currently watching what's left of my elderly family enter those final days of their own lives in recent years... oof. This hits even harder than I expected. I didn't cry right up until the final 10ish minutes. But then it was a full on ugly sobbing. I know these games aren't for everyone, as they really are more just slightly interactive stories... but they are stories with real, raw emotions. You owe it to yourself to give this one a go if you already experienced To The Moon. Thank you, Kan and the rest of the team.

144153999.review: Before playing this game, I would absolutely recommend playing To The Moon first to understand some of the root concepts of the game. Beyond that, the game itself is very immersive and the story is very touching. The twists that this plot develops are very interesting and followed down an emotional direction I wasn't expecting. Overall Finding Paradise is a solid game

143813506.review:
Finding Paradise (2do episodio de la saga), es una obra que trae de vuelta un calco de los patrones que dieron éxito a To The Moon, pero que a su vez consigue meter de lleno al jugador en su universo gracias a su apartado narrativo (su punto mas fuerte desde mi parecer). Es un videojuego que no es para todos, la finalidad de esta clase de games es despertar sentimientos en el jugador gracias a unos personajes muy bien construidos, una historia humana y muy peculiar, y a un apartado artístico (tanto sonoro como visual) sobresalientes. Si ni te gastaste en jugar To The Moon, o si lo jugaste y no te gusto, nt ya que es mas de lo mismo, pero si a pesar de no ser fan de los juegos point and click le queres dar una oportunidad, la verdad no perdes nada, ya que con entre 5h-6h te lo das vuelta y te llevas una experiencia emotiva privativa.
Muy recomendado para los que se engancharon con la saga de To The Moon.

143728884.review:
This game truly blew me away. From the numerous hidden references to the other games in the series, the music, that one animation, and the storytelling. While it certainly isn't as sad as To the Moon, it was still sad to me, the concept of death and seeing the photo album of the family really broke my heart when you realize death is coming. 

I can in no way say I get the full emotions of this game until the person playing it has reached that age in their life, only then can someone accurately look at this game and fully 100% understand and feel it's messages. Despite that, to make someone not at that age feel all the emotions truly says something about the level of storytelling.

143702016.review:
有一位女子，在湖中泛舟，与我琴笛合鸣——这是懵懂时代常常萦绕在我脑海中的幻想，像极了那个被称作《寻找天堂》的故事。

我自问不算一个会替消逝的事物惋惜的人，但眼下满目，尽是遗憾。
那些未说而再难出口的话，再也救不回的植物，锈蚀的旧日各样器具，
甚至还有屡修屡毁的硬盘数据，都成了再难弥补的过错和缺憾。

因为我是一个幻想家，我总能在事情发生之前，幻想最精彩绝伦的画面，
无人知晓，无人洞悉，它比现实，美妙千百倍。

我总是带着，诗情画意的镜片，但它不能帮我看清光怪陆离的人间，
所及之处，美则美矣，尽是镜花水月。它太吸引人，以至于，我常常迷失其中。

浩瀚的宇宙，固然有无限的可能，
悲凉的是，唯有一种可能能行至终点，
我要为一切被泯灭的可能伤怀。

那些遗落在幻想中、再没有机会照进现实的一切光影，
我或许，要用一生，来做绵长的诀别。

不过，岁月长河里，凄凉苦短的人生，
本来就在不断和各种人事诀别，不是吗？

There was a lady, plying a craft upon the water, harmonizing lute and zither - This vision frequently meandered through my mind during the era of naive innocence, resembling strikingly the tale so called Finding Paradise.

I don't consider myself one who laments for things elapsed, yet everywhere looked now, is filled with regret.
The words left unsaid and now too difficult to utter, the plants that can no longer be saved, the rusty relics of bygone days, even the repeatedly repaired and destroyed hard drive data, all have become irreparable mistakes and deficiencies.

Being a fantasist, before scenarios happen, I am always able to fantasy the most spectacular visions.
Unseen, unbeknownst to others, they outshine reality, thousands of times.

I always carry with me, glasses of a poetic and picturesque sentiment. But they don't help me see the phantasmagoric realm of humanity clearly. Wherever I go, pretty indeed it may be, yet merely mirages of beauty.  It holds such allure, that, I often lost within.

The vast cosmos assuredly holds infinite possibilities.
What is poignant is that, only one such possibility can reach the end.
I will lament for all those possibilities extinguished.

Those rays of light and shadow, once trapped in fantasy, and now forever barred from entering reality, perhaps I will, need a lifetime, to have a protracted farewell for them.

Nevertheless, within the long river of time, our brief and desolate existence,
is inherently bidding farewell constantly to various people and affairs, isn't it?

142183814.review:
No tenía altas expectativas con este juego, porque "To the Moon" realmente no necesitaba una sequela, y repetir el mismo concepto no me generaba mucho interés, pero "Finding Paradise", a pesar de seguir la misma fórmula, se las arregla para ser igual de bueno que el primer juego.

La banda sonora tiene una calidad muy similar a la de To the Moon, y está bien añadida en los momentos más importantes del juego. El pixel art continúa siendo muy bueno, quizás un poco mejor, pues se agregaron un poco más de variedad en los sprites mediante animaciones y expresiones.

La historia luce similar a la del primer juego en un principio, pero al final termina distanciándose de las semejanzas, ya que termina a abordando un tema muy curioso... y algo triste. ;_;

Sobre el dúo de doctores, me pareció interesante que se sientan más insensibles a lo que observan en su trabajo, pero aún sigo creyendo que no tienen mucha relevancia en estos 2 juegos, no sabemos mucho de ellos en realidad, por lo que me siguen pareciendo no muy interesantes al final. De todas maneras, ayudan a que la historia sea más ligera y cómica, y me caen bien la vd.

Supongo que lo que menos me gustó fue el misterio de uno de los doctores, ya que estuvieron un buen rato desarrollando intriga al jugador, para que al final no se termine explorando de la mejor forma ese tema. :p 
Tal vez en "Impostor Factory" avancen más con eso ¿?

..Pero bueno, está buena esta shet, recomendado por si quieres llorar y divertirte al mismo tiempo, aunque si no te gusta tanto los juegos más enfocados en contar una historia por encima del gameplay, entonces tal vez no te entretenga c:

142172455.review:
Wow... What an amazing story. Let me just say that I went into this game with zero expectations and if you love a good dramatic, well written story then play- no, [i]experience[/i] this game!

The few cons are:
[list]
[*]Slow opening. It kinda dragged for me and hooked me about 20-30 mins in. That's asking for a bit much, but if you get through it, it's definitely worth it.
[*]I really did not enjoy it's gameplay loop. I understand a certain mechanic is necessary to progress the plot but there are [b]PUZZLES[/b] involved and when you are wrapped into a narrative, they just completely take me out of the immersion and halts the flow to a sharp stop. I'd have appreciated a "skip puzzle" option.
[*]Walk speed. The walking speed is immersive but as a busy adult with precious little time, just let me dash here and there to quickly get to where I need to go. [i]Especially[/i] on backtracking segments
[/list]

Other than that, this interactive story is amazing. Once I pushed through the slow start, I was hooked on where the story was going and finished it in one sitting. The plot twist and ending was SO worth it. It brought me to tears. Again, this was a well written story, one that of such good quality I can literally imagine this being re-told in a live action production. Amazing!
Edit: Oh! THE MUSIC IS AMAZING TOO

Lo he intentado tres veces en los últimos años y no lo consigo, ésta ha sido la última. 138955979.review:
[spoiler]Thank you..for having been there when no one else was.[/spoiler]

Kan Gao and the team at Freebird Studios did it AGAIN. I was worried about playing Finding Paradise after To The Moon and A Bird Story, thinking maybe To The Moon was lightning in a bottle for me, but man did this sequel deliver. So many plot elements that I did not see coming, a genuinely intriguing middle section, and an ending that once again left me in tears.

The gameplay is basic and the game isn't very long - 4.5 hours if I had to guess - though I had to do the ending twice to get the achievement to pop (I played in Alternative mode for Pixel-Perfect) but the puzzles were very interesting and required a lot more thought that the ones in To The Moon. But the gameplay is still RPG Maker and while there were some fun moments towards the end [spoiler]The battle minigames against Faye and the climactic RPG battle that has two different outcomes[/spoiler] the gameplay isn't really the focus of these games.

But man I also loved that they took some expectations from To The Moon and subverted them. I won't say anymore to avoid spoilers, but you need to play this game.

Hopefully I don't take as long to get to Impostor Factory.

Sequel to "To the Moon".
Once again, a deep, emotional story (but with a lot of humorous moments) with a beautiful soundtrack that adds to the atmosphere.
There are some fighting minigames for those who like action, but they are optional and you can still finish the main game when you loose or skip them.

If you enjoyed To the Moon, then you will like Finding Paradise, too (personally, I liked it even better).
If you haven't played To the Moon yet, then I'd recommend you get and play that one first (or better: get a package deal).
If you enjoy the following, that is:

- Humor, including black humor, jokes and referrals to all kind of things
- Retro style pixel graphics
- Atmospheric background music

137926050.review:
[h1]Foreword[/h1]

I know, less than an hour playtime is not enough to deem a review; especially for this kind of game that you really need to finish through to 'properly judge' it. But hear me out when I say that I watched multiple playthroughs of this game and recently played and finished through it again with my fiancee on her account (after we finished To the Moon and Bird Story). I might play through it again on my own account just for novelty sake of having the series completed and the Steam achievement. Either way, I just felt the need to finally chip in my take on it as it is an exceptionally good game/story.

[h1]Not every story is meant to be told..[/h1]

But when they are, it makes up for a rollercoaster of emotions when flawlessly executed. The header being a partial quote from the game as I lack any better idea for another header title. Also because there isn't really much I can say about the game without potentially spoiling parts of it, and for a game that is all about storytelling I think it's crucial to leave it fully intact for new readers/players. In comparing it to the first 'episode' To the Moon, I will say that for me personally it was a bigger heartfelt tearjerker even though I felt To the Moon was a lot more melancholic. But of course this will differ for everyone because of the individual sympathy one may feel for each of the stories and it's characters.

The only real 'critique' I could give this game would be for the limitations of it's engine. But I wouldn't really call it critique more-so than something to keep in mind. The best stories are often told through simplistic engines such as the likes of visual novels, and RPG Maker happens to be one of the good old mediums that also offer certain interactivity. Finding Paradise does seem a bit more interactive than To the Moon was and it feels like they tried improving on it by introducing other new elements. The puzzles are still fairly easy and by no means do they impede on the story. Coupled again with another delightful soundtrack, it makes for a full course meal.

[h1]Words of Advice[/h1]

Realizing that I don't want to say anything else about the game that could affect someone's experience, I do want to close it off with some words of advice for a possible issue that some people may have with the game's engine. It will initially stretch to full-screen by itself which you can force to window mode by using the Alt + Enter shortcut, but it will be locked in a teeny little window. The former might also change your native resolution which may be a bit annoying. To solve that, just right click the game in your library and select properties. Then select the 'Betas' categories and select the 'alternative' version in the drop-down menu. This will install and update the game to where you get a proportionally correct scaled full-screen or a re-sizable window through using the same shortcut keys. Much needed if you don't fancy squinting or looking at ant farms.

Other than that, it goes without saying that I would recommend people play To the Moon first if they haven't and consider Bird Story as well for a much deeper context before starting Finding Paradise. In total these games average to about 4-5 hours playtime each (depending on how fast/well you can read) with Bird Story being a shorter one around an hour or so.

[i]"The ending isn't any more important than any of the moments leading to it.."[/i]

136578444.review:
What an adorable game!

Wholesome, relaxing, witty, with a lot of heart and deep insights.  
That's Finding Paradise.

I chuckled in the first 18 minutes alone more than I did in the entirety of other games that are tagged funny!

The story in FInding Paradise is exceptionally well written and the dialogues are engaging, feel natural and have zero fluff or padding. That's just good writing right there.

I enjoyed my time getting to know the characters and grew to like them. It helped seeing how their differences make for amusing moments, like how the serious Eva assumes the mantle of the more responsible adult to the playful and anime-obsessed Neil! 

Some characters also complement each other as in how a certain loopy and free-spirited character pushes the overthinking Colin forward to do what he wants to but is too timid to do on his own.
   
The music score is simple and perfectly sets the mood for the heartfelt story. It also masterfully changes according to the scene.

I was going to list the game's lack of Steam's screenshot functionality as a negative, but on second thought, it isn't. Sure it sucked not being able to share special moments in the game but all in all, it's actually better that way to avoid giving away spoilers.

The game has an extended scene with the full works, including dialogue, animation and accompanying music score, in homage to the opening scene of one of my favorite movies of all time. :] I won't say which so you can have fun with it when you do! 

There were moments when I felt like I'm in Tron Legacy while playing this game. One of the best things is that some parts are skippable without affecting the game's outcome. 

It took me 9 hours to play the game from start to finish while exploring everything and going through all the dialogues. There's only one achievement in the game that pops up once completed, so you can just enjoy the ride.

If you really want to know what the game is about and don't mind a semi spoiler, here: The doctors' core job in Finding Paradise is an improvement on what you find in that Jim Carrey movie [i] Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind [/i] meets the Animus from Assassin's Creed meets Make a Wish foundation. 

If you watched the movie and played even one AC game, then you can imagine the possibilities of where the story can take you! If you haven't, even better, you'll experience this yourself first hand :)

Play Finding Paradise when you're tired of long RPGs and shooters and just need to relax with minimal gameplay and a simple, engaging story that may or may not leave you with something to ponder about life in general. Highly recommended even for newbies to the Point and Click genre, like myself lol

...[i]wow[/i].

This has to be the most captivating game I've ever played. The story was beautiful, intriguing, fantastical; it was such a wonderful experience in every way. The accompanying music was truly gorgeous, it really set the mood and made every scene feel so much more real, warm, and true. The art is fantastic, a little varying in terms of consistency, but not at all ever bad. The only negative, and the sheer wonderment I felt while playing completely toppled and tossed this aside, is the script-based engine/gameplay does feel slightly clunky, but it really isn't that bad and you quickly acclimate and don't really notice.

It'd be a disservice to anyone looking to play this game, to explain its story or any elements to it. The first half an hour made me think this game was going to be pretty simple, with a gentle story. It was so much more. It shattered my expectations and transcended to a higher experience. I haven't felt emotion while a story was unfolding quite like this, ever.

A marvel of fiction. A testament to how great a game can be by just having a rich, complex story filled to the brim with somber excitement.

5/5, 7/5, 10/10, 100/100. Whatever grading you prefer to use, this deserve the highest rank.

I needed a good cry since it's been a month now that my dad passed away near Valentine's Day. I've been coping well until I played this game where the patient Colin reminded me so much of my dad. Very secretive, wasn't easy for him to share his emotions, hardcore loner, huge storyteller that would either exaggerate to keep simple scenarios more interesting or tell something true that was unbelievable to process & so on. My dad didn't have the best life growing up which I believe was unresolved trauma from dealing with his father growing up but it didn't stop him from achieving his dreams after my mom shown him what freedom is like.

There were hurdles for sure but the both of my parents survived with what they could. Me being part of the picture renewed their hope and well now I'm here writing this review. I'm not even talking about the game itself since I've never played something so short yet so impactful at the same time. I'm familiar with FreeBird's previous game To the Moon which I'm sad to say I don't remember much since high school a decade ago. The game had some slow down while reading notes but other than that the game ran fine and the mouse was a good QoL improvement unless the original had that too.

Anyways before I get too sappy I definitely recommend the game if you're dealing with grief either buying full price or on sale.

133843225.review:
I have never ever encountered a more pathetic egotistical and solipsistic character than the protagonist of this game. 
Boy grows up in a happy and loving family. Because he is inept and lonely makes up an imaginary girlfriend. Grows up, meets a woman who loves him, gets married, has a son, has a fulfilling and long career and is otherwise healthy. But as his end of his life journey approaches he is miserable. And the main reason is that he misses his imaginary friend whom he put aside when he grew up enough to have his son. 
So he decides to make a contract with that company so they artificially fulfill his last wish on his deathbed by altering his memories somehow. All this while his caring wife and son left hurt and betrayed, wondering what they did wrong and can't understand why he'd choose an artificial memory instead of them.
While the doctors traverse through all his memories, the vast percentage of them is the imaginary character. His marriage, birth of his son, career and other real life important events only occupy a small fraction of them. 
That empty shell of existence could never make a connection that deep with his wife and son as the one he had with his imaginary friend. Not even at the end of his life.
And this is the character that everybody in the overwhelmingly positive reviews are identifying with and crying for.

132109676.review:
Beautiful. Poignant. Moving.

After having played To The Moon some years ago (which should be played first) I thought I was ready for Finding Paradise, and doubted it could hit the emotional highs of its predecessor. I was clearly wrong.

I often feel a lot of gaming reviews overhype emotional writing and storytelling ability, especially compared to some of the best movies, television, books, and other media, but Freebird games have proven with this series that they are the masters of writing impactful, interactive stories that somehow reach deep into your most core feelings and emotions and bring them to the forefront. Using oldschool RPG Maker graphics to strong effect, a simple but highly engaging soundtrack, and a pair of amusing protagonists, Finding Paradise slowly unravels a story that I suspect will resonate with many adults and make them want to reach out and hug their loved ones after (I sure did).

If you're looking for an example of "games as art" or "games as highly effective interactive storytelling," you'd struggle to find Kan Gao's beautiful series. Highly recommended.

132039903.review:
Finding Paradise is the 3rd (2nd full) installment in the To the Moon series. The story follows two individuals; Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene. The two provide a service that allows individual's to have another chance to live once again from the beginning. The only drawback is that it's only in the individual's head. Due to how the service works, the last thing these individual's will remember is the second artificial life they live in their heads, and because of this is only offered to those that are on their deathbeds. 

The story encompassed within Finding Paradise isn't one that tries to hide the overall narrative. Perceptive players may realize early on what is going on, and others may realize only when the game tells them. The answer is always there to begin with, the pieces are just out of order. In the process of reviewing the patient's (Colin's) life the player lives and experiences another's lifetime. By the end, Watts and Rosalene must discern what Colin most desired and provide him with it. Some may wish for riches, status, or a dream vacation, Colin's wish isn't quite as simple and cannot be easily explained. The story doesn't stand out due to luck or various other events, but because of how simple it is. Colin's story could easily be our own experiences and his desire in life to be what many of us also hope to achieve. The story in Finding Paradise works effectively because of how easily players are able to relate to it with their own experiences. Which in turn allows players to empathize with the characters feelings in certain events. 

The Music and Art of Finding Paradise are intricately sewn into the story as well. The music and sounds amplify the mood of the scenes and can turn what was a seemingly humorous moment back into a serious one. There wasn't a single moment while playing where I felt that the music didn't fit, or noticed an obvious loop in a track. The music here flows seamlessly into the next scene. The art is all original and beautifully animated. There are multiple minute animated details that further draw in the player ranging from the playing of an instrument, to a character taking the extra step to lay down on the ground. Simple movements we see in our everyday lives but in many pixel based games are often overlooked or unneeded based on the genre. It's the care that is placed into these small details that further bring the game together and allows the narrative to flow seamlessly from one point to the next.

The puzzles of the game served as a reference point for unlocking a memory through a physical means from the player. This was likely to stimulate not only the idea of how memories are tied together through repeating objects of interest in our life, but also the action of recalling a memory. That moment in time when we stop to recall and think upon a memory from a long forgotten moment. 

In the beginning I didn't like how slowly it seemed the characters walked, and instead tried to find a way to progress around the map faster. It wasn't until I went through a few memories that I realized I didn't care about that anymore, and now having finished the game am glad there wasn't a run. The game told the story at its pace and no faster. When it wanted you to run, you would run; when it wanted you to walk, you would walk. This kept the game flow consistent but also allowed the player to establish a connection to the story and dwell in the moment on the events within each memory. 

It likely comes as no surprise that by the end, when the story has been played out Colin passes. The service is only provided to those on their deathbed after all, and yet despite this I still felt as if I had lost someone close to me when that heart monitor finally fell flat. That's when it really hit home just how well Finding Paradise was able to get me to care about the characters and their story. It's games like these that remind me why I continue to play smaller indie titles over games from larger studios. Because at the end of the day the stories that stick with you are the ones that left an impact on you. It's the games that made you care about the lives and stories within them, and that is exactly what Finding Paradise has done for me. I look forward to playing the rest of this series, and the other stories that are left to be told. We only live once, but if you had a chance to live again, even if it's all in your head, would you take it?

131935845.review:
[quote][b]S U M M A R Y[/b][/quote]

[u][b]Finding Paradise[/b][/u] is a linear, story-centric interactive RPG from the [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/franchise/FreebirdGames]To the Moon[/url][/u] franchise. It directly follows the story of [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/206440/To_the_Moon/?curator_clanid=2750327]To the Moon[/url][/u] (plus its DLC) and [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/327410/A_Bird_Story/?curator_clanid=2750327]A Bird Story[/url][/u], and precedes [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1182620/Impostor_Factory/?curator_clanid=2750327]Impostor Factory[/url][/u]. Overall, I highly recommend it due to its fantastic cast who is fun to be around and spend time with, its great writing and jokes, its gripping story with unseen twists, the very interesting premise that forms the core of the franchise's worldbuilding, and its absolutely amazing soundtrack.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]A C H I E V E M E N T S[/b][/quote]

The game has a single achievement which is acquired when you beat the game. A normal playthrough takes around 5-6 hours depending on how much you explore the world to try and find extra conversations between the characters but, as of the writing of this review, the world record time for a speedrun of the game is 2:26:04 so you can finish it much faster if you're just in it for the achievement.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]R E V I E W[/b][/quote]

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The gameplay is fully linear while the interactive elements have a minimal amount of interaction but these suit the game just fine since the gameplay acts as an accompaniment to the story (which is the true crux of the game). The interactive elements involve walking from point to point, exploring restricted areas in order to find and collect objects required to progress, solving a number of "match 3" puzzles which have some unique twists to them, a few other unique mini-games, and optionally exploring the more open areas to find extra conversations between the characters. However, I do have two gripes with the gameplay: the characters walk around [i]very[/i] slowly and it would be nice if they walked a little faster to shorten the travelling aspect since it doesn't add much to the game, and you are limited to three save slots which is very little in this day and age.

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
The graphics are very pleasing pixel art reminiscent of the later 16-bit era of games ([u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/613830/CHRONO_TRIGGER/]Chrono Trigger[/url][/u], Star Ocean, etc). The sprites are very well animated and the character expressions are quite clear which both really add to the emotion of the game.

[h3]Sound[/h3]
The music is comprised of a number of atmospheric songs, which are used more often and suit the mood of the scene that they accompany quite well, and a few beautiful piano pieces which are used for the more pivotal moments in the game. In both cases, the music is fantastic and is a joy to listen to even on its own. The credits song is also a pleasant change of pace with its inclusion of vocals.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story is the true heart of the game and I found myself captivated by what was going to happen next at every point in the game. The post-credits scene took this a step further by making me very curious about what will happen next in the series and the world as a whole. The gripping story is supported by its very likeable and relatable cast of characters, the amazing jokes and puns (especially the funny phrases that are sometimes used in place of swearing), and the enjoyable light-hearted interactions between the characters who have been developed very well over the course of the franchise so far.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Overall, I highly recommend this game. In fact, I began to clap when the credits appeared and I'm extremely excited to play [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1182620/Impostor_Factory/?curator_clanid=2750327]Impostor Factory[/url][/u] so that I can see what else happens in this world. I have high hopes for this franchise and will continue to support it for as long as the developers keep putting out quality content, and I hope you do the same as this is definitely a developer worth supporting.

I absolutely adore this game, and I feel like as a whole experience it's definitely an amazing upgrade over To The Moon. Even if it didn't hit as many people. I wholeheartedly recommend it for anyone that even remotely liked the first game, I am not the biggest fan of comparing the two in quality when I think both are amazing standout experiences.

Overall even if you don't see eye to eye with what the game tries to tell or make you feel, it's writing quality and amazing soundtrack is apparent to everyone who may touch this.

(Spoilers for both this game and To The Moon.)
[spoiler]It definitely resonated with me though, To The Moon's brilliance is how much Johnny's childhood memories are a culmination of every single detail the game was building up to, and I feel like the reason most people find those scenes so utterly and universally heart-wrenching is because it essentially is a gigantic explosion of sad realizations and incredible sound design and pacing.

Meanwhile this one is a bit more complicated, Finding Paradise definitely relies on having some sort of relatability and resonance for it's core to really drive itself home, it's big emotional moments aren't culminations of plot reveals or sensory overloads but just putting it's themes on display, themes I might add that are a perfect continuation and utilization of the series' premise, that kind of approach though has definitely made it less universal and some particular plot details less relatable to a lot of people apart from the simple idea of being largely lonely and wanting to have done more.

Even with it's very few caveats though I think this is an absolutely marvelous piece of media, and it's writing quality is easily seen even if you weren't able to completely align yourself with the story, I would easily rate this game a 10 out of pure recency bias and feels but I feel like an 8.5 or a 9 is more appropiate, I will definitely hold this experience as near and dear as I hold To The Moon and hopefully Imposter Factory when I get to it.[/spoiler]

129836664.review:
I'm not really sure what the point of this game was.

To The Moon was pretty barebones, but it could get away with that through its novelty. It may not have had much depth to it, but it introduced some neat ideas and wrapped it up in a story that was pretty good given its brevity.

Finding Paradise has much of the same core as To The Moon. The core concept of a machine that can rewrite memories shortly before death, the same two characters overseeing that process, and a dying patient with some sort of lingering regret that they want fixed. But a sequel needs to do more than share the same core. It needs to either go deeper (exploring the original's concepts and ideas in greater depth) or it needs to go wider (introducing additional ideas that somehow mesh with the original). The problem with Finding Paradise is that it does neither of these things, instead resting on the laurels of the original game without anything new to say about them. 

Even putting the lack of new ideas aside, the core story still feels like a downgrade. The patient is far less interesting of a character and the stakes are far lower. More attention is shifted to the machine operators, Rosalene and Watts, but I honestly found this to be the worst aspect of the original so the increased focus here is honestly a net negative.

I suppose if you really loved To The Moon and want more of the same, this might still be worth your time. But to me, this was a pretty unsatisfying way to spend a few hours. Its not terrible but its definitely bland and that's quite a disappointment considering how much room there actually was to innovate on what made the original game good.

129150176.review:
I'll say this much, "A Bird Story" did NOT spoil this game at all, but that won't change my opinion of THIS game. In fact, having finished "Finding Paradise", it feels like playing both of these games was a waste of time.

SPOILER WARNING, I DON'T CARE

I'm sorry, because I can see the passion and creativity behind this, and I'm sure there are plenty of people who love this, but I thought "Finding Paradise" was WORSE than the other two.

My same criticisms from the other games still apply here; it's a story that doesn't work as a video game, because it's too automated and doesn't give the player enough wiggle room to actually interact; the first act repeats the same formula of finding a bunch of "memory links" to a "memento", travelling through time, and then daisy-chaining different memories across a person's life together. The two scientists still spend most of the game fighting back and forth and annoying each other, making them poor protagonists to see the story from their perspective.

But the story here isn't even GOOD. 

There's an interesting subplot where Dr. Watts is tampering with his company's equipment, and his colleagues start demanding answers, but it's just there to set up the plot for the next game. 

Besides, the main plot is one big paradox. It has good ideas, such as how a person's outside experiences can sometimes alter their memories, and how an imaginary friend can influence a person both internally and externally.

But here, the writing hammers you on the head with its message, and it makes the plot of this game, as well as the premise of the whole series feel pointless. All it boils down to is people can alter their own memories to make themselves happy, and they don't need to hire scientists to put them through an expensive process with fancy gadgets to do that for them. Even then, people don't HAVE to alter their own memories if they got everything they wanted, and only had a few embarrassing moments along the way. That's what I got out of this game.

I can only recommend this to hardcore fans of "To the Moon" and "A Bird Story". Anyone else will be bored at best, annoyed at worst. 

Once again, I suggest watching a Let's Play and buying the soundtrack on the developers' Band Camp page. This time, it'll REALLY save you the frustration.

129141178.review:
You know, this game was in my library for months. I had only recently gone through my un-played games, and remember adding this game because I love "story-rich" categories.

Actually playing through this, it really went from a solid 3 to a 11/10. It started boringly, and seemingly like a game that just had some pixels to it and not much story driven. Then I just kept playing on, wondering when it would get to the good parts. I am very happy I stuck to my motivation of getting the one and only achievement.

This game was so simple, but so rich. The visuals added so much depth that I would take over a 4D game any other day. The music. so familiar and so comforting. In the end, everything was like a circle that came back to you like karmic deeds. You never knew whether it was achievable or not. There were a few times I stumbled my way through the story line and just had quotes I related so well to. And now when I have finished the game, I don't think my crying will stop. Because this was a tearjerker. Why did I not get a warning about that?

The story that was slowly building up. The tensions, the battles between the characters, and the simple back and forth banter that fleshed the characters so well - it was heartwarming.

Thank you for making this game. I enjoyed playing it to my fullest capability.

126576315.review:
En primer lugar recomiendo jugar To the Moon primero si por alguna razón no lo has hecho, aunque no es estrictamente necesario.

Finding Paradise es exactamente lo que una secuela debería ser: Más de lo mismo, pero sin ser lo mismo. Es una historia que te va a hacer reir a ratos pero sobre todo te va a hacer llorar como una magdalena, igual que la precuela hizo tan bien. Considero que ambas son obras maestras y es cuestión de gustos cual os parece mejor pero merecen ser jugadas y de oferta son un auténtico robo. ¿3 euros por llorar y que me pisoteen el coraçao? ¿Dónde tengo que firmar?

Si algo tengo que criticar como negativo es que los protagonistas son meros espectadores pero el problema es que tienen una trama que se intuye que puede ser muy interesante y que ya en To the Moon y sus mini episodios te dejaron con el caramelo en la boca, y en esta entrega no se resuelve ninguna de las dudas, simplemente meten más misterios en la ecuación y puede ser frustrante para las personas que no les gustan los misterios sin resolver (y más teniendo en cuenta la de años que han pasado). No sé si en impostor factory resuelven estos misterios pero espero que sí.

En cualquier caso no me voy a adentrar en la trama. Simplemente pillad una tarde tonta que tengáis 5 horas libres y jugadlo del tirón, hacedme caso.

P.d: ''A bird Story'' es una especie de precuela de este juego, pero en realidad no necesitas jugarlo para entender este, así que lo dejo a gusto de consumidor. A bird story es una historia de una horita con 0 diálogo y pura comunicación no verbal y muchas cosas raras. Al que le guste que lo pruebe.

125550743.review:
TL;DR  "EMOTIONAL DAMAGE"

Perhaps I'm a sucker for psychological dramas about love, loss, and the trauma involved. Finding Paradise is a simple story that tackles the deeper questions of finding and treasuring what's truly important in life. I fear if I say any more though, I may spoil it for any other potential readers. Succinctly put, it struck a chord in me. I'm not even sure how I discovered To The Moon/Finding Paradise series, but boy am I glad that I did!

With all that out of the way, do I recommend this narrative experience? Wholeheartedly and undoubtedly YES!!! I enjoyed every second of my time spent with Doctors Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts on their quest to grant wishes to two very deserving individuals. I very much look forward to any future stories from the Freebird Games team. Thank you so very much for these tales!

125344267.review: This hit me even harder than To the Moon (I know, I am a soppy doofus). Beautifully written continuation of our two favourite Inception-artists, Eva and Neil, who this time around are being asked to amend the regrets of a dying man despite the fact that he has lead a full and happy life and the issues that this brings with it. Once again we have snappy dialogue combined with retro gaming homages and grand themes around whether we should be holding onto and cherishing our regrets that made us who we are or seeking to delete them forever. Amazing stuff with more feels in  the 2d sprites than many AAA ‘angsty’ games (looking at you, A Plague Tale: Requiem).

125064156.review:
A more thought-provoking storyline, but not having the level of emotional connection with it's predecessor (which was instead spent in Neil's mystery). 

Thoughts
---------

If Colin didn't know about Sigcorp, then he would be content with his life (even with regrets), but Faye in his subconscious wouldn't have realized to emerge at his last moments and ask how his life went (he wanted that meeting as well, say goodbye to her and finally be at peace, but couldn't imagine her consciously) - thus masterfully showcasing the quote about "instead of finding the right answer, it's about framing the correct question". This necessitated Sigmund's interaction in his life, which made Faye emerge through amplification of the machine, and the interaction of the doctors made her realize on what she needed to do. But in the process, they also needed to remove their own existence, so that any other aspect of FOMOing and changing his thoughts from Colin's mind.would be vanished. Finally, giving her power over the machine and her doing the correct thing showcases the morality aspect in the story. 

Colin's request also makes us ask the question whether the existence of Sigcorp is good/bad in general (hits hard when you think if it existed irl, and people would actually think this), if we from the aspect of people who think whether they have made the right life choices,

124277501.review:
[b]My Playtime:[/b] 4.6h (100% achievement, finished the game)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Finding Paradise[/b] is the second main title from [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/206440/To_the_Moon/]To the Moon[/url][/b] ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198132503739/recommended/206440]my review[/url]), a story-rich game from [url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/FreebirdGames]Freebird Games[/url]. It starts sometime after [b]To the Moon[/b], with the same concept of two doctors that are digging into a dying man's memories to fulfill his wish. [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/327410/A_Bird_Story/]A Bird Story[/url][/b] ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198132503739/recommended/327410]my review[/url]), a side story that was released between this and the first title, was also connected to this game and will give extra information for those who have played it.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Beautiful music that helps to bring out the emotion of the story
- Interactable objects that can be easily missed are made sparkle to make it easier to notice
- Puzzles for more variation to the game

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Slow walking speed and you can't sprint to speed it up
- Some texts are advanced automatically without confirmation
- Sound effects like question marks and sleeping can be hard to see due to the background color

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like [b]To the Moon[/b] and want to play another game with similar storytelling, buy this game, although expect it to be of lesser quality.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
[b]Finding Paradise[/b] uses the same style as [b]To the Moon[/b] with interiors that rely on ambient lighting and soft, piano music that accompanies it. Just like its predecessors, characters' sprites are drawn in great detail: instead of reading what the character was doing from a dialogue, you'll see them doing it in action. This helps to focus more on the narrative, especially since there are a lot of action scenes in the game. The ending also becomes more impactful with this decision, showing what matters with so few words.

[h3]Story[/h3]
Just like [b]To the Moon[/b], [b]Finding Paradise[/b] uses the same concept of two doctors that are trying to fulfill a dying man's wish. Those who have played the first game might think that they will experience the same procedure, but the game gives a little twist. Since the original procedure won't be explained in detail, those who haven't played the first game might feel overwhelmed with the amount of information, especially since they need to process existing information from the first game on top of new information that is happening in this game.

Dialogues are short and brief, making them easy to digest. There won't be any wall of text for you to read, and conversations use words that are easy to understand. However, there is no way to automatically show the whole dialogue in full unless you play the alternative build, and the default text speed is slow.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1775803988

The main theme of the story can be a bit vague. Unlike [b]To the Moon[/b], the doctors are tasked with a harder case that can leave you to speculate. What is the best way that you can do to fulfill the patient's wish? What is the cause of his regret? Those kinds of questions will linger in your head as you play, and the game does no better than giving a vague conclusion to them. It's as if the developer wants the players to reach the answer themselves, which can backfire when they couldn't arrive at an answer. I felt like I was missing something after seeing the ending despite knowing what happened.

The story has a lot of mysteries. In addition to the mysteries from the first game, you'll also have more from this one. To be honest, I was more interested in this than the main story, simply because there wasn't much information about what was happening and I couldn't make any guesses. Moreover, I already had assumptions about what was going on in the main story early on so I had some room for thought.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1332070449

However, despite all the vagueness and mysteries, the story can still get as emotional as it could be. I admit that I was confused when the game was almost ending - I was in denial that the game was ending and was thinking that there could be something more that I missed. However, I also had my share of confusion as to why it touched me so deeply without me realizing it. I usually could feel emotions coming from miles away when I was playing emotional games, but with this game, tears came out of my eyes before I realized what has happened. It could be because of my age, or maybe it's because of the game's charm, but honestly, I'm lost for explanations.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Just like the other games from [i]Freebird Games[/i], [b]Finding Paradise[/b] combines both story-heavy narratives with interaction scenes. You'll move from place to place all the time, interacting with objects that you think can give a clue to what happened. It wasn't hard to find the objects either - you can guess them based on the patient's favorite subjects, and the others that don't will have sparkles on them. Moreover, there are hardly any vast areas, making exploration to be quick.

There are still some areas where you have to do a long walk, though, and the slow walking speed irritates me. I hated the default walking speed since the first game and wished that the developer will increase it more this time. They didn't. Well, there are some areas with an increased walking speed, but it wasn't there where I had to walk a long way at the beginning. Luckily, interactable objects are usually not that far most of the time.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1236245179

[b]Puzzles[/b]
There is a customized match 3 game where you need to move some objects in a grid to make a line of 3 or more of them. The game was easy to pick up and serve as a good way to alternate between the whole repetitions of walking and talking. There are also other minigames, but they can be skipped if you are having trouble with them.

[b]Length and Replayability[/b]
I finished the game in 4.6h. There is no replayability - there might be some options that you can choose at the beginning, but I don't think it matters much to the main story. I was impressed with how smoothly the dialogue flows after each option, though.

[b]Issues[/b]
The game was surprisingly slow to me. I had to switch to the alternative branch just to play it normally. The branch, however, has some differences from the main game, such as the font difference, the lack of achievements, and the feature to show the full text without waiting for the whole text to load. I believe that there is also a scene that was different in the ending, but it might be just me since I didn't pay attention to the game when I replayed it in the main build for the achievement.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Finding Paradise[/b] tries to reuse the same concept as [b]To the Moon[/b] with a twist. I'm glad that they took this approach because the story will be too predictable and boring with the same procedure, although the story wasn't as impactful as the first one. This game focuses more on its mysteries and how well you can understand the theme that was subtly told in the game, which can be hard to be understood by some people. However, it strangely manage to touch me with its emotional scene, and that one particular scene was done very well as a finale. If you like [b]To the Moon[/b]'s storytelling and are eager for more, I suggest buying this game.

122712946.review:
Wow. 

Finding Paradise is a beautiful (and at times pretty funny) story about life. The twists and turns in the story keep you guessing, and after some of the more intense reveals, I was not prepared to need tissues. 

Highly recommend for someone looking for a good story. If you haven't, you may want to start with To the Moon for the initial introduction to Eva and Neil.

122680558.review:
After reviewing To the Moon, it is time for another work of art from Freebird Games. Finding Paradise brings us once again the dynamic duo of the well-known doctors from part one.

This time Eva and Neil face a greater challenge with Colin, who feels like he has not lived a fulfilling life and wishes to clear out all his regrets. The thing is, he wants the doctors to change something… without changing anything at all! Is it even possible? Will Eva and Neil find a way to make that happen and discover Colin's paradise? That is what I will leave for you to explore. But trust me, the experience is worth it.

It would seem that the sequel would blandly match the first instalment of the series, To the Moon, as that’s what usually happens when a game gets its continuation. But that prejudice is wrong. Finding Paradise perfectly equals in quality to its predecessor while offering a completely new, more intricate plot. At some point, I even started to feel connected with Colin since his story felt somewhat relatable to me. For this reason, I dare say that this game has hit me harder on a personal level than To the Moon.

I feel like it is worth mentioning that Finding Paradise can be played with or without knowing To the Moon and A Bird Story (a short prequel to FP). So if you are familiar with the previous games, good. You will notice some references to them in this instalment. But if not, then all is not lost. You will, either way, understand the plot and take pleasure in it. And that's beautiful about this series. 

Buy this game discounted or at full price, get carried away on this journey, and let the tears flow at the end!

当童年的纸飞机最终飞回手里的时候才恍然意识到已经长大了。
成长没有准备好一说，只有当那一刻来临的时候才知道。
成长如此，很多事情亦如此，所以有了遗憾。
但是孤独的日子会使得相逢那天焕发光彩，遗憾未必总是悲伤的。
Colin的一生很短，读者走马观花只用几小时，
恰如他自己所说的“不知怎的时间就不够用了”。

这个故事像往复的早晨给爱人的一个吻一样，平淡却如此饱满令人生羡。
Faye的爱是鼓励支持且包容的，而Sofia的爱是长情的，眼前的。
但两者都是无条件的，真实存在着的。
因此Colin可以说是非常幸运的。

120277414.review:
This game sat in my library for a while because it was on sale. And I procrastinated playing it, since pixel games are not really my type. But a friend recommended it, so I got it,
However – this game surprised me!

But, looking back I would rather not recommend the game, as it does have several issues.

SPOILERS AHEAD!

Writing style
I liked the story itself a lot, but I feel like the writing style is a bit off for the theme. The random whacky humour broke immersion for me and I felt like the tone of the scenes got either interrupted or destroyed completely which was rather annoying. I could appreciate some of the jokes, but it just didn’t fit the theme they were going for.

The story
I feel like, you will either love or dislike the story depending on how much you can relate to Colin. The theme feels very niche as it is about imaginary best friends and how you outgrow them. 
I could relate to Colin but didn’t understand why he “regretted” so much. I could understand that loosing something is hard, but I didn’t see why he regretted so much. Especially when it was some minor thing that made his life in my opinion more memorable (in a good way even!). He had a pretty good run actually and his only regret is saying goodbye to his imaginary friend? He does realize that Faye is part of his imagination and could bring her back any time?
While I found the slingshot concept super intriguing, I wish the pacing would have been way better. Because there were so many moments that felt like they didn’t matter at all. Why is this a core memory?  The game has 3 Acts, but 80 percent is just Act 1, 5 percent Act 2 and the remaining 15 percent Act 3. It feels very unbalanced.
That being said, Act 3 was a bit annoying to play. Faye is most of the game quite unlikable to me (but who am I to judge – it is his imaginary friend after all), but the way she refuses to talk with them and just makes Colins state worse, makes no sense to me at all. 
But I did like the ending. It actually made me cry a little. I found it heart-breaking, that the imaginary friend died alongside of him. I didn’t cry because of Colin, I cried because it reminded me of my own imaginary friends that I had as a child and that they will die once my life has ended as well.
I also like the overall message of; having regrets is okay and makes your life more memorable. 

Characters
The Characters were decent, a bit too whacky for my personal liking but at least they had edges! Which is always a welcome change. However, while I could relate to certain parts of Colins life, I couldn’t understand why he wasn’t satisfied. Why he dwelled so much on something that could have easily been brought back? Sofia and Asher felt so insignificant in his life compared to Faye.
The doctors kept interfering with the story with their bickering. I would have found them charming on their own but not in the context of the game.

Lore
I found myself wondering if I accidently skipped text boxes because I had a few unanswered questions. Also, the introduction of the two characters that you play felt a bit sloppy. Only at the end I realized that this game was a “Part 2” of a series. The story does work on itself, but I wish I had known before that this was a continuation of a series.

Soundtrack
The soundtrack is very cute, even though it got a bit repetitive, I still liked it.

Game style
As I already said I am not the biggest fan of pixel art, so I am biased here: but it was pretty cute and decent for my personal liking.

Game mechanics
Easy enough but sometimes a bit buggy. When you clicked on the memory it sometimes made the characters walk away from it while applying the colourful balls. It was not a big hassle though. 
Overall way to repetitive for me, with the same puzzles over and over again.
I think I would have enjoyed an interactive story more than the “gameplay”.
The ending was a bit more difficult. It has a fight/defeat mechanic that is retro. It is probably easy if you play these type of fighting games, for me personally it was a bit hard

Although there are some flaws regarding the story, specially the conclusion of it, I still think the positives overweight it all. The entire journey was an enjoyable experience, and the messages here presented were powerful enough to teach me good lessons in the end (at least by the time I played it, those ideas were things I had never thought about before). Finding Paradise helped me change my perspective in life in a positive way, and therefore I highly recommend it.

118622810.review:
[h1] 𝕐𝕠𝕦 𝕤𝕙𝕠𝕦𝕝𝕕 𝕠𝕟𝕝𝕪 𝕡𝕝𝕒𝕪 𝕥𝕙𝕚𝕤 𝕘𝕒𝕞𝕖 𝕒𝕗𝕥𝕖𝕣 𝕪𝕠𝕦'𝕧𝕖 𝕙𝕒𝕕 𝕒 𝕤𝕙𝕚𝕡𝕞𝕖𝕟𝕥 𝕠𝕗 ℂ𝕝𝕚𝕟𝕖𝕩 𝕥𝕚𝕤𝕤𝕦𝕖 𝕕𝕣𝕠𝕡 𝕒𝕥 𝕪𝕠𝕦𝕣 𝕙𝕠𝕦𝕤𝕖! [/h1]

"Finding Paradise" is a direct sequel to "A bird story" that follows another episode from Sigmund Corp; the company that works in the field of granting people's last dying wish! Although the game is quite emotional at times, the same inconveniences that plagued the other Freebird games are still present here.

You control Dr Eva Rosalind and Dr Neil Watts, the same two "clowns with deep understanding of human emotion" from the game "To the Moon" who, again, are assigned another case of an old dying man with a wish that could be granted. Upon arrival at the scene, Rosalind and Watts immediatly sense that this is not a regular case and they'll try their best to grant Colin Reed's dying wish; who is the same little boy you played as in "A bird's story", the same lonely kid with tons of regrets. In "Finding Paradise", Colin Reed seems to have made a life and a career for himself, and you'll see it all unfold in glorious pixel-art graphics.

Let me warn you though, that the game will have you choking of depression throughout; I literally cried the first few minutes of the game when Colin is talking about how his life was great but unfulfilling, that although he loved his family, he's had many things he regretted not doing... Such as spending adequate time with his son, who's had a career and kind of ghosted his parents for the entirety of his adulthood... These little things in the game will have a deep effect on your emotions because they are as ordinary as they are real things most people will go through in their lives not paying too much attention to! I guess you'll have to play the game to find out how deeply-rooted in our lives these things the game details are... Hence why you'd require lots of tissues to get through Colin Reed's life and give him a proper farewell.

The things I've stated before that you should be aware of before getting the game are: The fact that the game's resolution is capped at 640x480, you can only change it to look like a small tab in your huge monitor. The Steam Overlay also does NOT work with the game, and you'd have to perform unnecessary maneuvers to get the game to properly function. Is the story so good that it's worth looking over all of these defects? Yes, it most certainly is. Despite all that's bad with the game, in my opinion this is one game that deserves a sort of prize, an Oscars or something... It's a [b]10/10[/b] emotional journey through an old man's memories; it will have the toughest of players beside themselves with grief, if not straight out crying their eyes out. Play it only when you're in a good place mentally, or it might make your depression much worse before it makes it better.

117968268.review:
Spoiler-free for those coming from To the Moon (which my review for was lackluster purposefully):

IMO, the story's not quite as emotional (but I still shed my fair share of manly tears). In To the Moon (TtM), the experience is shorter, telling a story that is both as sweet as it is saddening. Here, Finding Paradise offers more extension to TtM's storytelling format, and instead insists to tell a more complicated story using the same medium. In fact, I find the story significantly more complicated to a point I believe I'm either gonna have to replay this game again in the future, or read up on it to wrap my head around it - just to fully understand what exactly happened in this game. This is not a flaw. I am just stupid.

Mechanically speaking, though, I find that FP has better sound design and music - and I note for the music in particular, I noticed a fuller, richer listening experience and generally it seemed the music was designed with better articulation. I digress. From a gameplay perspective, the option of using WASD for movement and Spacebar for interaction was an excellent feature that TtM lacked, as it was limited to arrow keys for movement and Enter for interaction. The art in FP also seems to have improved - environments felt more realistic, more colorful, more atmospheric. Animation quality was largely the same, as TtM's animation was already above what you'd expect from a pixel art game already. And lastly, TtM's comedy dialogue felt more awkward and forced, but I actually found myself chuckling quite a bit during FP. Maybe it just grew on me.

Overall, TL;DR - Finding Paradise is a head-scratching, thought-provoking, emotional experience that is comparatively different than it's predecessor. For as long as Kan Gao maintains consistency in writing what I find to be truly real, immersive worlds containing real people who have feelings, I will continue to buy and play these games. 9.5/10.

117362441.review:
Finding Paradise is the sequel to To the Moon and involves mostly the same things. It's a story with some walking/talking segments along with with a few puzzles.

This begins at some point after the events of To the Moon. Dr Watts and Rosalene go to change the memories of a dying guy named Colin. Slightly different in this one is that instead of going from old age to youth, this one flip flops back and forth between the two, converging at middle age.

Gameplay is mostly walking & talking to people, looking at objects, and an occasional puzzle segment. The puzzles are obnoxious but rarely take more than a minute to complete. The slow walking speed can be annoying on occasion.

Finding Paradise is mostly decent in everything else that it does: Stories, dialogue, characters, development, etc. Unfortunately, the problem is that this ends up only being decent, mostly due to the plot.

Without spoiling anything, the problem with the plot is it almost entirely goes in a circle with very little expanded upon. There is only one tiny change made for Colin, so it ends almost entirely the same as it started and leaves you with little to nothing to reflect upon.

Even more disappointing is that the side story of whatever is happening with the doctors is barely touched on here. Maybe two or three very small things occur involving it, but they barely expand what is happening. Unlike To the Moon, this does not have any free DLC that provides more on that side story.

To touch on some smaller issues with the plot, what is going on in the plot was pretty easy to figure out well ahead of the reveal. On the plus side, that means it's fair and you don't feel cheated since you could figure it out by paying attention. On the downside, it's not really impactful. Even worse than this is that at some point during the story, two other doctors from the company show up. One of them flat out states that he thinks he knows what's happening..... and then just leaves without telling Watts or Rosalene. Colin is dying. He may not have time for Watts and Rosalene to figure it out, and the doctor leaves without saying anything. Could you imagine if a doctor couldn't figure out some issue with a patient, another doctor knew what it was, and then just didn't bother telling them, especially if the patient was dying? This is easily the worst written part of this as it's distracting and annoying. This would have been way better off by removing it and simply having the other doctor being confused by what is going on as well. It adds nothing and only destroys your immersion.

Finding Paradise isn't bad. It's enjoyable enough. Its problem is that it isn't good due to the plot issues.

This is...different. Overall I enjoyed Finding Paradise once I finished it but the game definitely could have done with some slimming down. Excluding pointless minigames would have helped as well, I don't play feelsy games for weird anime combat sections lol.

Much of the story is good, right up until you start delving more into one particular character and things start getting bizarre. Queue minigames you almost always lose and the plot totally derailing...or so it seems. Things come together near the end and the finale hits like a ton of bricks, so I would say this is worth playing through.

Achievement hunters, you're looking at between five and six hours to complete FP, mostly depending on your reading speed. Only one achievement and it's unmissable which is nice.

Suggested on sale or in a bundle, Finding Paradise is good but not on the same level as [i]To The Moon[/i].

112537851.review:
Finding Paradise follows the familiar formula of other games made by Kan Gao and his team. It's a deeply emotional story with some interactive elements.
If you played the earlier games (A Bird Story and To the Moon), you should know that this one is related to both of them. You will meet some familiar characters, and even will be able to get to know them better.
What separates Finding Paradise from the previous Freebird games is that it has more interactivity. There are some mini games that you require you to do more than just walk around and talk to people. While some might find them distracting and even unnecessary, personally, I enjoyed playing them. I think the mini games serve the same purpose as Dr. Watts' comedy relief moments: providing a nice change of pace, and making the story less "heavy".
If you value the games that have an actual well-written story with believable characters, I can't recommend Finding Paradise enough.
