111042495.review:
I played this game in 2022.

I am highly interested in [b] Impostor Factory [/b] and of course some good people in the review (thank you for that!) recommend to play [b] Finding Paradise [/b] before playing [b] Impostor Factory [/b]. Fortunately, good folks there also recommend [b] To The Moon [/b]. Here I am, trying to send the same message because hey, I am one of those who can't decide which one is the best between these three.

I played and finished all these game in 3 days, and I must say that it was a wonderful journey. The writing is superb and the music is very phenomenal. There were some issues with the older game, but it was just very minor compared to overall experience in playing this game. These three games are the good games that make you reflecting your life and asking yourself questions about life. 

The storytelling in this game is exceptional, you can feel the sadness, laugh awkwardly at the dry humor, feel proud for the character's achievement, and even roll your eyes at some jokes. The story is one of the strongest point of these three games, I highly recommend you to play this game without any walkthrough or read spoiler to enjoy the game to maximum level. 

The music in this game is truly phenomenal it deserved a special paragraph in this review. I regrets that I only played [b] Impostor Factory [/b] using my headset. If you have a proper headset or headphone, try playing these games using your headset/headphone to appreciate the music. Do you still want to hear the music after finishing this game? Do yourself a favor, all the soundtracks are in Spotify for you to stream.

Try these games. Totally recommended.

110211130.review:
10/10 would recommend for fans of the series.

This is good continuation from To The Moon. The story and music are still top notch. Sadly the mechanics and puzzles are still trash and it would probably benefit from veering nearer to a walking simulator style IMO. As I played through I really couldn't imagine this tale being told through any other medium but an interactive media one, so props for that I guess.

This game has everything.  But first of all let me say something to clarify for those who haven't played any of the Freebird games games that this game is VERY STORY INTENSIVE.  And that there is not much interactivity really.  I mean you do a couple of little chores and stuff but that's to get the STORY.  It's ALL ABOUT the STORY!!!  So, if you just wanna play a mindless game with no story go for it, and you most likely won't like this. For those of you who are wondering what is the correct order to play the Freebird games is, then I will tell you.  The games before To the Moon are not related in story.  And after that it looks like this:

To the Moon
Minisode 1
A Bird Story
Minisode 2
Finding Paradise
Impostor Factory

107150014.review:
[h1]The grass on the other side, is it only greener in my mind?[/h1]

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] This is the second chapter in the current To The Moon trilogy, though perhaps series would be better used, as an end doesn't seem to be in sight.  The wiki uses 'The Sigmund Corp Series,' so I think I'll use that as well.  As such, the visual style has been kept constant.  The characters of Neil & Eva bounce off each other quite well, both with their individual quirks.  The additional characters from Sigmund Corp are a welcome touch, & adds a character that seems to be more vital as the games progress.  Each has their charm as they delve into the mind of their next client, though travelling through in a collapsing spiral rather than a strict timeline this time.  The music stands out just as well as the last, & yes, "Wish My Life Away" by Laura Shigihara is definitely the highlight.  Similar to "Everything's Alright," it's used during the climax to great effect.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] Sadly, only one of the real problems from To The Moon has been fixed.  The game still has a large problem with a plodding 1st act, an incredible sparse 2nd act, & a short but slightly frustrating (though emotional) 3rd act.  The puzzles feel completely unnecessary, & the sudden actions taken in the final act can be a tad annoying.  At least they improved the characters this time around.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENT[/u]:[/b] Once again, a single achievement unlocks after clearing the game.  Enjoy the story, & receive your reward.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Finding Paradise is a charming, sweet, heartfelt follow up to To The Moon.  If you're coming in to continue the lives of the Sigmund Corp workers from the first title, & have your heartstrings tugged, it fills that niche quite well.  However, with that said, one must be prepared for a very similar experience to the last.  Perhaps don't play these titles back to back.

107136800.review: Outstanding adventure games have two major components in which they have to excel. The first component is the level of puzzles the player has to solve, and a great adventure game increases the difficulty and complexity of diverse puzzles as the story develops while providing enough clues that the player AFTER solving the puzzle thinks “That was rather obvious, why didn’t I think of this from the beginning?”. The second component is the emotional involvement of the player in the story development; an identification with the problems the characters encounter to provide a driving force for the effort necessary to solve the puzzles. Rarely, adventure games address both components, with LucasArts games starting with "Maniac Mansion" or “Sally Face” being exceptions from the rule. Most games put much work into the first category while neglecting the second leaving the player wondering why-o-why one should even care to find out that you have to put the alien snail into the blender and feed Cerberus with the snail juice. The Freebird Games “To the Moon” and “Finding Paradise” are on the opposite end of the spectrum, and the puzzles are extremely simple. But the emotional impact is so heavy that this barely matters; if anything, the simplicity of the puzzles ensures that they slow down the game to a speed that the players can digest the implications of the story for their own lives. Of course, I prefer the perfect symbiosis of the two categories as exemplified by games like “Thimbleweed Park”. But if I had to choose one of the two extremes, pure puzzles or pure storytelling, I definitely – DEFINITELY – would prefer the interactive mangas of Freebird Games. You might not want to call them adventure games, but who cares if this is such a deeply satisfying experience.

The game takes around 6- 10 hours to finish.

106690247.review:
tl;dr: Play this for an afternoon of laughter, intrigue, and tears. Favourite RPG of all time.

To The Moon's sequel, I feel, does everything the first game did better. When there's humour, you laugh harder. When there's a twist, it makes more sense. When there's an emotional moment, you actually cry.

I loved To The Moon for its characters, but its story (being Johnny's back-story) was cliche and kind of forgettable. By contrast, Colin's backstory is just as memorable as the characters you play as. The themes presented in this game are almost entirely unique, anything I've seen before could only loosely be compared to it.

My only gripe with the game was perhaps unavoidable with a story you can finish in an afternoon; the tense, objective-threatening moments near the end seem kind of tone deaf compared to the hard-hitting emotion of a few minutes prior. Fortunately, I can't say the same for the spot-on humour.

Anyway, this game is great. Play it when you have the time.

106562384.review:
Finding Paradise continues on To the Moon's narrative, bringing the same characters, slightly different procedures, and the same heart-warming and heart-breaking ability in a different story.

Like To the Moon, I enjoyed Finding Paradise's story; accompanied with the right music at the right times, certain moments were made memorable to me. [spoiler]Finding Paradise introduces a rather interesting twist that I hadn't seen coming though, and it made the story much more fascinating.[/spoiler] Finding Paradise's excellent visuals compliments the story throughout and was very enjoyable for me to play through. At the same time, though, the game play can be fairly long to some people (it took around five hours for me), so play at your own pace!

All in all, Finding Paradise is an excellent sequel (of sorts; there isn't much of a link between To the Moon and Finding Paradise, so you can play this separately) in the To the Moon franchise. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a story to play through!

105691194.review:
To The Moon was the first game that I can remember making me cry. It hit home with something raw and deep in my soul, something I still struggle to define. When the sequel came out, as excited as I was for it, I was so afraid of experiencing emotions that primal again that I put it off for years.

Now I've done it, and all I can say is, it was worth the wait.

Finding Paradise is an evolution of Freebird Games' abilities. It digs into similar themes to its predecessor -- love, loss, isolation, and the bittersweet despair that comes with the end of a long and storied life -- but it explores those themes in a completely different way. And when it's not rooting out your heart, it's hitting you with Kan Gao's effortlessly sharp comedy, or building up some genuinely eerie mysteries that climax in a scenario I could never have seen coming. It's a breathtaking ride encompassing so many different levels of what it means to just... be alive. I don't know how else to describe it.

10/10. As with To The Moon, this one's going to stick with me for a long, long time.

105155554.review:
Beautiful little game/interactive story for the most part, loses it's way a little in the middle but comes back together.

If you've not played a Freebird game before, please start with "To The Moon", whilst you could play this first there are things in there that will not make much sense without starting at the beginning.

Told in chapters just like it's predecessor the narrative is easy to trigger and follow, with the memory fragment searching being no challenge to get in the way at all.  The mini-games to trigger movement to the next memory are more consistent and interesting than in the previous game but still unlikely to take more than a minute each.  You get a couple of "choices" during the game (whether to divulge info or not type questions) but they have little bearing in the end, just pick whatever you think more interesting.  The story is told in a memento style (end to end meeting in the middle), the "twist" is well played if a little too heavily foreshadowed.

Where the negative comes in is the mid section where the antagonistic part comes in, which as a story device is understandable but goes on for far too long when you know it's only going to end one way, the "fight" scenes getting very repetitive as proving to be pointless in the end.  It's a bit like the developers played Evoworld between the first and second games and felt the need to shoe-horn in a massive change of tone when it was really unnecessary.

That said the game does recover from this by the end and finishes up telling the story in the right way.

105153424.review:
Another classic: the wit from Eva and Neil returns here while also expanding them as characters with how they act around their coworkers or with the situation that they're in this game around. Music is amazing as always with Laura Shigihara returning for another fantastic song. I also love the theme of this game this time around.

However I will say that I found one portion within act 3 concerning one character sort of whiplash-y? There's something really cool here and I love how they started it off, but in some ways thats ruined by how they handle it later on. I also found the subject of this game, Colin, while charming and fun, found there was almost a lack of presence in his own game. Its a bit of a shame because he's not a bad character or anything, he's just not really around here somehow.

Overall I love this game and its a classic, and compared to To The Moon, it may not have the same emotional punch and lacks some of the strong subject characterization, but its still a fantastic game that I thoroughly recommend.

105064863.review:
Si bien entré a Finding paradise con cierto excepticismo, es mucho lo que me encontré.

Para jugar a este título es indispensable terminar To the moon así como sus DLCs, ya que la historia vivida en el primer juego permite comprender los hechos narrados aquí, así que si no los has jugado, te los recomiendo.

Entrando en materia, este juego expande el universo de que nos ofrecía To the moon y juega con nuestras expectativas a nivel narrativo, creando una historia familiar y a su vez, diametralmente opuesta.

Se desarrollan aquí nuestros dos personajes principales de la saga, su relación con la empresa y sus inquietudes a la hora de dar una segunda oportunidad a sus clientes, así como los límites éticos.

A su vez, se nos expone una historia de superación y aceptación por parte del cliente de este juego, con ciertos toques dramáticos y un desenlace que a pocos dejará indiferentes.

Las primera mitad del juego sentiremos estar reviviendo el primer título y quizás mucha gente desista al ver pocos cambios en el comienzo de esta historia, pero es en los pequeños detalles de esta primera mitad donde se le habla al jugador de que este NO es el mismo juego.

Dejando de lado el apartado narrativo, el juego explora nuevas mecánicas y (en algún momento puntual), nuevos géneros.
Aquí, el motor gráfico usado (RPGMaker) parece ser el cuello de botella para hacer un titulo mecánicamente más avanzado que de profundidad a estas maravillosas historias.  

Te recomiendo este juego si te quedaste con ganas de más tras to the moon.

An experience well worth your time with one warning: brace yourself for the most painfully cringe, mood killing attempts at humor you'll see in a narrative game. Younger players may not mind it so much, but for most adults it will be hard to believe that there was one writer of the game's otherwise continually intriguing, tightly paced, and mature story.

This series continues the clunky and dated RPGMaker gamefeel but admirably pushes its limits with plentiful contextual animations, novel mechanics, and an excellent soundtrack. The story has several twists and turns but stays pretty easy to follow while giving you something deeper to chew on in the broader philosophical themes. I just wish I didn't have to endure the unbearable affectations of the playable doctor characters to get to the good stuff.

100093370.review:
After the way To The Moon had me crying, I thought it might be worth a shot picking up the next game in the series from Freebird Games. They say all their games can be played on their own, but there were a lot of little callbacks and references I would’ve missed if I played this game first. While I can’t say say that I didn’t enjoy the game, it definitely was nowhere near as good as To The Moon

When quality gameplay and graphics are basically nonexistent in a game, you have two legs left to stand on; story and music. With the first game, it didn’t matter that the graphics looked outdated and that there was pretty much no gameplay. The story was THAT good, and the music complimented it very well. While I would love to say the same about Finding Paradise, I just can’t. Despite the music being good, it wasn’t enough to save it. The story was so confusing and strange that I just wanted answers. Yet the game kept giving me questions. I understood the message they were trying to relay in the end, I got it. But it still didn’t leave an emotional impact on me like To The Moon did. And when the biggest element of the entire game falls short, you kinda run out of reasons to recommend it.

Do I regret my time with Finding Paradise? No, I think in the end it just had a mediocre story which maybe I would've enjoyed more if I hadn't played To The Moon first. It's like trying to compare a seven course meal at a five-star restaurant to a burger from Chili's. Was it absolutely terrible? No, but because I've had better, I know what was missing. The ending felt like a cop out for coming up with something actually intriguing. It was really disappointing because I really wanted to like this game. I was waiting for it to blow me away, just like To The Moon did. But that moment never came. And in the end, I was just left confused and unsatisfied.

99317924.review:
[h1]A distinct, beautiful and impactful story[/h1]

[i]Finding Paradise[/i], the sequel to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/206440/To_the_Moon/]To the Moon[/url] [spoiler]and [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/327410/A_Bird_Story/]A Bird Story[/url][/spoiler], picks up from the same universe with the same kind of question: if you could change anything, what would it be? But even if the initial premise is the same, the exploration of human life, memories, and values in Finding Paradise is dramatically different from the game’s predecessor.

This time, the focus is on a dying man named Colin who seems to have lived a happy, fulfilling life with his wife Sofia and son Asher. His dying wish isn’t immediately clear, but discovering what he means by it is a large part of the story. Rosalene and Watts delve into Colin’s memories, exploring both his recent experiences and his earliest recollections from childhood to determine what factor they can change so that he believes he lived a fulfilling life. Throughout the story, we simultaneously experience the most important moments in the life of a dying man and the playful yet tense relationship between Rosalene and Watts.

It is not necessary that you have to play [i]To the Moon[/i] or [i]A Bird Story[/i] to understand [i]Finding Paradise[/i]. The subplot with Dr. Watts doesn’t make much sense if you’re not at least familiar with Sigmund Corp’s work and Watts’ cliffhanger ending in [i]To the Moon[/i]. [i]A Bird Story[/i] offers a bit of context to Colin’s plot, and though it is recapped briefly from the character’s point of view, it helps you understand how his mind works a bit better and may help clever players predict the game’s biggest twist.

Overall, [i]Finding Paradise[/i] tells another “side” of the themes established in a world where Sigmund Corp lets people live unrealities in their final moments. Its characters are beautifully flawed and believably human, which gives the game room to say a lot about the ways we process, shape and contextualize reality and unreality without shoving a moral up our nose by the end.

98583396.review:
I doubt that words will be able to explain how much I hated this game sometimes. 5 hours out of the 5.6 hours this game took from me were dreadfull and horrible. After 4 hours I was set on writing this solely with my middle finger...

While the ideas for both To the Moon and Finding Paradise are really really interesting, the game fails to move me in any way. The first Act is really repetative and you have absolutely no idea what is going on. The gameplay is okay though, not interesting but not frustratnig either. The only thing absolutely atrocious is the minigame you have to complete in oder to move on to the next memory. It was bad in To the Moon, it is worse in Finding Paradise. Second Act was the abolute WORST in any game I have ever played. The style changes completely and you understand even less of what it happening in the story. Weird cutscenes and old-style video game fights are thrown at you and you waste 30 minutes to an hour probably of clicking through whatever is going on on screen (comparable to the weird zombie shooting part in To the Moon). There were moments I just wanted to throw my laptop against the wall just to end it.
Act 3 was surprisingly pleasent, then for a change and I almost regreted wantig to give a negative review. The end and resolution were cool and well presented in cutscenes; the final moments in Colin's life were beautiful.

The game does not have content for 5-6 hours of gameplay, though. It really dragges on and results in boring repetetive mingames and weird content to add more time. The story could have been told in 2-3 hours. I personally often wanted to skip cutscenes or endless dialoges that did nothing really.
FInding paradise has a lot of potential and I somewhat get why people enjoyed it. But it failed to get me interested in Colin until the very end, I had no emotional connection to him, was annoyed by the repetitions and filled with hate by the horrible fighting sequences.

98014067.review:
The premise of this game is amazing. The company you work for go to dying people and "fix" their memories to match up with the person's wishes in a previously made contract. That alone is reason enough to buy it for it's originality. The result is to be expected; a view of many important moments in a person's life. That is why it is so powerfully moving for other's in the comment. Inevitably, you will have to look at yourself along that journey. 

The graphics are pretty good for pixel art. The music is fitting and beautiful at times. The story and mood of the game is it's main selling point. 

Where it flounders are minor annoyances. Let me run. I guess it does break immersion for some, but the game's story drags a bit, and at times it was very much like reading a book. You are almost done, but you want to stop reading for the day but you feel compelled to continue and can't stop. I ended up finishing it in one sitting. With that said, running, or maybe a shortening of the story to make it more succinct would have been good. But the story is still great. 

The other is that I wish there was a log of what was said somewhere. This game allows skipping dialogue (one click writes out the whole two lines of text if you are a fast reader.) 96682135.review:
If you've played To the Moon, then you'll be familiar with Finding Paradise. The sequel is longer than the original and includes more gaming elements, though -- like the first game -- only a few scenarios near the end actually depend on your gaming skills. The main focus here, like in the first game, is the story.

Eva and Neil work for an agency that gives people their dying wish by altering their memories to play out right before they die. In To The Moon, they were helping a patient who wanted to go to the moon. In this game, however, the patient doesn't have a specific wish in mind. There are other complications and, like the first game, there's a twist.

Is Finding Paradise better than To The Moon? In some aspects (such as gameplay), it's improved on the original, though I noticed typos in the dialog that I didn't notice in To the Moon (mostly concerning verb tenses). But the original story is stronger and more heartfelt. I still cried at the ending to Finding Paradise, which is more beautiful and cinematic than any game has a right to be, but I cried more at the ending of To The Moon.

Still, if you loved the original game, you'll enjoy this one. And if you haven't play the original, you should.

Do you want more quirky humour from our favourite doctors? Would you like to learn the complex life behind their current patient? Do you crave more from these awesome developers? Yes yes a hundred times yes! Then jump into Finding Paradise, another well written game with a rather fascinating look into the memories of a man on his last legs and a peculiar dying wish. 

This story is just as good as the first and I found myself not wanting to stop playing as I delved deeper into this old man's life. The developers did really well here, changing the style of how the memories are linked due to the patient's past experiences and how that shaped his mentality. 95231305.review:
Definitely not as good as its predecessor "To The Moon." The story was much less compelling, Colin was much less interesting as a character, and overall the plot felt more hocus-pocus to me. Much of it can be attributed to Colin's ambiguous wish of a "fulfilling life." Without a clear goal, Eva and Neil were aimlessly wandering around and were simply moving along just to progress the plot. I was hoping the story would focus on his regrets, but instead, it pivoted completely, culminating in a relatively neutral-feeling ending, with a decent message and a "meh" conclusion.

Still, the method of story-telling was quite cool, as it mimicked the style of Christopher Nolan's short film Memento, jumping back and forth between the beginning and end of the timeline, such that we finish at the middle. I thoroughly enjoyed how it wasn't just a simple reverse chronological path back to Colin's childhood.

Furthermore, the plot twists and action do spice up the story and do make the game entertaining, though not to the heights of its predecessor. I just wish the story took a different direction and took out some of the hocus-pocus pieces (some of which felt like filler / "trying too hard" to me).

In the end, it's still a worthwhile play, but this isn't a game I'd be dying to recommend to others or a game that I'd ponder over for hours after playing. It is simply "a good game" -- nothing to write home about. It was never going to be another "To The Moon," an impossible ask anyways.

95219149.review:
[i]Finding Paradise[/i] is a sequel to [i]To the Moon[/i], and I think that it was decent overall.

I would say that the most important aspect of these games are their stories, and I will admit that the first game really hit me and actually made me tear up when it finished. This game, however, failed to do so, and I think it was actually more because of its pacing.

To be as vague as possible, there is a plot thread that you can see coming from far away, but the game spends way too long unraveling it. Hence why my emotional connection sort of wavered a bit, I think.

Other than that, the game is essentially a cleaner version of [i]To the Moon[/i]. Your job is to grant someone their dying wishes by modifying their memories, so you have to trek through their past and find special items ("mementos") that you can use to connect to other times in their life, all while you figure out how best to grant the person their wishes. There's some grid-based puzzles each time you unlock an item, but they aren't too difficult. Other than that, the game is mostly walking around, inspecting things, or talking to NPCs.

I think the art direction is very nice, as is the music. For a 2D RPG Maker game, it has great atmosphere. But overall, I'd actually suggest starting off with the original game and then giving this one a try.

95141371.review: Story wise, I would certainly say this game meets expectations. It is without a doubt on par with it's predecessor To the Moon in that field, and in some cases even exceeds it. The devs also pushed the boundaries with the gameplay and aesthetic, making for a much more interesting game to look at and play. The soundtrack is alright. It's pretty good, again on par with To the Moon, but don't expect some sort of a musical masterpiece like in Undertale or the like. In terms of bugs/glitches, I didn't experience any. At times the game lagged and the text sometimes loaded slowly, but I'm pretty sure that's moreso an issue with the engine, RPG Maker, rather than the game. I would highly recommend it if you've already played To the Moon. If you haven't played it I would advise you do so, as it sets up most of the ideas and some of the main characters so it won't make as much since if you haven't played it. There are also references to it throughout the game, so those won't make sense and the game will be spoiled if you haven't already played the first one. Overall, I rate this game a solid 9/10, and I am very excited to see what the devs come up for their next game.

94801320.review:
[SPOILER WARNING!] [i]Summarized story and my thoughts.[/i]

Finding Paradise is more lighthearted than To The Moon, but still a unique story of its own. Reminds me of my childhood, but I didn't enjoy playing this as much. You play as two doctors who use some kind of machine to traverse through a dying man's memories and reshape them to fulfill his last wish. His last wish was to be happy. Colin, the main character in game, never grows out of his childhood traumas and it stops him from achieving real happiness in life. Despite years and years have passed... having a good life and everything he could ask for, he is still a fragile kid inside that won't let go of the past hurts and so he lets it rule his present and future. He is missing something that was never real, his imaginary friend, because at that time he had no one else to turn to. His own family couldn't truly make him happy, because he never lets go of the past. Colin's last moments are spent talking to his childhood imaginary friend about the life he had. He had everything, the only thing missing was his friend to be real. In his own world, it was real in the end. 

[i]"Thank you for having been there, even when nobody else was."[/i] Colin's final words to his friend.

Verdict: Finding Paradise is a game worth playing for the experience and something to think about deeply.

94262651.review:
Finding Paradise is a standalone developed by Freebird Games, the developer of To the Moon. Playing To the Moon first will make you understand the context that appears several times in the dialogue in this game. But if you only have Finding Paradise in your library, it's not a big problem. It doesn't reduce the fun you will feel when playing this game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2494317987
Finding Paradise, if I compare it with To the Moon, gives a more relevant impression to its players. It tells about the feelings of leaving the sweetness of youth days and growing into someone more mature and realistic in life. It also touches a bit about schizophrenia, but I can't cover that aspect for those of you who may have the same situation because it's beyond my capabilities. But if I have to generalize, then I'm taking it on par with the other things that are part of growing up (this is from a non-depth point of view, okay). Finding Paradise also tells about the feeling of emptiness that happens to someone who may look fine from the outside. Even though someone's lives seem comfortable and prosperous, it doesn't mean that his lives are already perfect. Well, sometimes there are times when we are alone and think only about ourselves and realize that there are things that have personal value and are difficult to be shared with loved ones around us. We don't mean to give less appreciation to those who always support and are always there for us, but it is undeniable that it becomes a puzzle piece that doesn't fit with the others.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2494314298
I highly recommend Finding Paradise to anyone who admires RPG with poignant stories. You should also give it a try if you like light games that you might finish in one sitting. 93297228.review:
[h1]What I liked: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Story is a roller coaster of emotions
    [*]Humor and charm
    [*] Music and feels
 [/list]

[h1]What I didn’t like: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Slow walking speed
    [*]Mini-game mechanic
    [*]No voice acting still
 [/list]
[h1]My Score: [/h1]
[b]A[/b]

[h1]Quick Summary [/h1]
A short indie game that is mostly walking around kind of slow to a story that I have to read and yet I was engaged. If you want a story that might start out slow, but build to make a grown man go through wide range of emotions to a climax that will break anyone. This is basically one man’s vision and while niche he’s got the skill to make what most people in video games can’t, a compelling story focused on characters we care about.

 [h1]More in depth: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]WITHOUT SPOILING THE STORY, which is the whole game, this review will be hard. It centers on a man, who we go through his life just like their previous games. To the Moon focused on the regrets of not going to the Moon by not becoming an astronaut, because of emotional reasons and stuff, to not spoil that game. 

    [*]Finding Paradise focuses even more on a wider cast of people, like his parents, two women and his own family that is not cliché like you would expect. The  core focus is on two relationships and what friendship, passion and happiness means even if you’re actually happy with your life and don’t have any regrets, IT’S A WEIRD THING, TO BE HAPPY AND NOT AT THE SAME TIME, this game does it right unlike me describing it.

    [*]The GAME IS PLAYED ONLY FOR THE STORY which has the classic you can just watch someone else “play” it and watch and it will be the same experience, but it’s up to whether you want to save money and able to skip the short gameplay stuff or get someone else to watch it with, like a movie. I wish I had someone to do that with. While it DOES HAVE SOME PUZZLES when dealing with activating memories, it’s either go to some objects that then starts this little matching mini-game that I feel was put in to make sure it has “gameplay” which people like me would criticize for not being a game. But the game is played for the story and doesn’t need artificial gameplay to justify anything, these are not hard but could easily be removed and improve the pacing.

    [*] The STORY DEALS with loneliness, what meaningful friendships mean, expectations of one self and loved ones that hit really close to home to me and might be why I loved it so much. The humor is charming enough at times that even though there are some misses, you’ll move on and enjoy the next one, you can tell this guy loves making pop culture references as there are a lot of those in here.

   [*] Their previous titles live in this universe and don’t need to play to enjoy, but it gives callbacks and further expands the world and some characters.  I didn’t play A Bird’s Story and it has some potential big payoffs if you played it, but it doesn’t affect this one, as the story is self-contained, it just gives those that invest heavily into this “franchise” more reasons to love and care which I just loved the scene with the paper planes notes back and forth on the balconies, and almost all the flashbacks which is basically the whole game, lol
 [/list]

[b]PAID: $3 [/b]
[b]COMPLETED IN: 5 hours[/b]

93261333.review:
Finding Paradise is a great sequel to To The Moon, and delivers a similar-feeling story while still managing to feel fresh. I really enjoyed this game and can easily recommend it to people who liked Freebird's other entries, with the usual caveats: the humor is a bit spotty and occasionally leans too hard on being self-aware, and certain emotional moments feel a bit too built-up and intentionally melodramatic (kind like you can sense the game asking "are you crying yet? isn't this so sad? eh?"). Obviously none of these gripes are game-breakers, but they do grate after a while

Finding Paradise also gives us a few more hints about the corporation that the protagonists work for, what's going on elsewhere in the world, stuff like that, and it's all surprisingly compelling. By the end of the game, I found myself really looking forward to the sequel, Impostor Factory, whenever it releases

93004440.review:
Many of the reviews to this game stated that it was much less emotional than To the Moon.  This lulled me into a false sense of security, thinking that I could play this game in the presence of others.  I confidently launched the game and drank in the nostalgia of once again accompanying Dr Rosalene and Dr Watts on a case.  I was further placed off guard by the charming humor and back and forth between characters.  It lulled me into a false sense of security as I drank in every aspect of the game and the story.  I followed along, enraptured by the events on screen,  trying to silently connect the dots and anticipating what the major emotional bombshell in the game would be.  The game kind of fooled me for a bit.  There were a few moments when some interactions between characters moistened my eyes.  Not a cry... not a sob... not enough for a tear... but MOIST.  I thought that was it.  I HAD WON!  The game had not bested me.  

Since none of you know me... I feel I should elaborate a bit on this now.  Just so you understand... I am a crier.  I cry ALOT!  Sometimes for things that aren't even sad!  If it really touches me in a way I will cry.  Tears will flow.  There's no stopping it... the dams break and the water is unstoppable.  To the moon?  CRY.  SOMA?  CRY.    Subnautica?  CRY.  The Witcher 3?  CRY.  Dark Souls?  CRY (But only because I was mad). 

I think you get it.  I cry.  

So... I was feeling triumphant over the game.  I thought it was over and I HAD WON.  Then the shoe dropped and the game revealed its hand.  I knew it was happening too!  Without spoilers, there was a scene we had seen so many times before that suddenly clicked with me and took on a brand new meaning... and I cried.  

But, I didn't just cry.  Oh no.  There was no mercy here for me.  The game put its foot on my neck and proclaimed victory as I sobbed... SOBBED.  I'm talking Ugly cry.  I'm talking... inconsolable.  My throat hurt, clenched from my emotions and me desperately trying to reign them in... but there was no helping me.  My face seemed to leak from everywhere.  Days after I finished this game... I still carried the emotion and sadness.  I watched some lets plays as well and cried all over... EVEN THOUGH I KNEW  WHAT WAS GOING TO HAPPEN.   

Anyways... the game is great and I am so thankful I got to experience it.

10/10, would (and have) cry again.

92828198.review:
A human story about last wishes and regrets. Feelsy, tender, and slightly long drawn. 

[h2]Story [/h2]
We follow employees of a company which fulfills final wishes through a computer hooked up on the clients brain. Through memories the final wish is contracted, and this is the majority of the story. We get to know Colin, the story's client, from every stage of his life. 

[h2]Gameplay technicals[/h2]
An RPG-maker game, with good animations and music. There is mouse support, however the mousespeed is tied to the original resolution, meaning it's very high on fullscreen. Keyboard works better, although a controller works too according to a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198014150309/recommended/337340/]friend[/url]. 
Along the story elements the game has a few minigames. Easy of nature, but does require some quick responses. 

[h2]Thoughts... [/h2]
An easy recommendation, with the average reception being so highly praised. Despite that, it's not a masterpiece for me. I'm unsure why exactly though... I should be able to identify with the client, having the same job, and somewhat facing death. Maybe it's because of that, that I identify less with the motives presented ingame. At one point I felt the story was being stretched way too long. 
I had a similar experience with 'To the moon' from the same developer. 

Despite that it's not entirely my jam, a thumbs up! 

70/100

91061246.review:
I thought the first half of the game was more engaging in trying to understand why Colin didn't feel fulfilled yet why he wasn't keen on really changing anything. Faye's purpose made sense, keeping Colin company and helping him figure out what he wants in life, supporting him when his parents were absent etc, but the story felt a bit slow. I felt like Colin could have been more fleshed out at times, since there was such a focus on his flying yet we don't see as much depth into him or Sofia (whereas with "To The Moon", I felt like there was depth shown in BOTH characters equally). I liked how Neil had reservations about things and was wanting to do more than just stick to the contract, that showed his progression of character, that he cared and made an effort, though I was expecting some revelation about him taking the pills, possibly affecting his job or something. There were a lot of great moments with Neil in this game, "This hookshot is the hookshot that will pierce the heavens!" and "QUIT PUSHING ME OFF EDGES, EVA!"), and quite a few throwbacks to the first game. I think one of the strengths was the music; it felt more varied while still keeping a theme song, but adapting that theme into many scenes without it feeling stale or overused. The "mini battles" were a fun addition to the game and not what I was expecting, but felt a bit too drawn out in terms of finding Eva, traversing through the memories again, and facing Faye yet again. I wished we could have seen more of Colin and Sophia together (at least we got the montage at the end), but I appreciated that it wasn't a case of an unhappy or problematic marriage, or that there were any cheap revelations that undermined Colin's love for his family. 

Another thing I really liked with "Finding Paradise" was that, despite the familiar dialogue between Neil and Eva and the banter, it didn't feel like a repeat of "To The Moon". Johnny and Colin had different lives. Johnny underwent trauma and grief while Colin lived mostly an ordinary life, just dealing with loneliness, especially at home. While I would say "To The Moon" excelled in story and I was more invested and found the characters to be far more memorable, "Finding Paradise" touched on a philosophical level of acceptance in terms of one's life and death. Colin sought fulfillment, yet it took him awhile to realize he already had it. He had to understand that it's okay to have regrets and at the end of it all, he wouldn't trade any of it in. That's a great reflection on our humanity. 

Overall, the story was not as powerful or as compelling as the first game in my opinion, but it was still a solid and worthwhile experience.

90796108.review:
One of the consequences of growing up [other than more responsibilities], is coming into a realisation that certain times and thoughts will never come back. Pretty sure the expression "good old times" is often said by plenty of people; the nostalgia of living in a carefree world, the dreams we failed to achieve, our regrets, the things we left behind. Everyone keeps saying to enjoy our life to the fullest, yet I don't think we will ever fully understand that until we miss it.

89727763.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

89462617.review:
[h1]tl;dr[/h1]

If you like stories about the human condition and you don't mind a fairly severe lack of game play, this game is for you.  Is it as good as To the Moon?  No.  Is it good?  Yes.

Do you want a game with fun game play?  Or great graphics?  This might not be the game for you.

[h1]pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Beautifully told story
[*] Thematically interesting themes that make you think
[*] Pleasing sound track
[/list]

[h1]cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] Weak game play.  It really consists of just walking places, clicking the interact button, watching things play out for the most part.  There's a few puzzles that are quite simple.  This also does have a few sequences that change things up for... like all of 2 minutes but that's about it.
[*] Graphically it's Super Nintendo era style graphics.
[/list]

89462285.review:
In order to not sound repetitive, I'm going to use TTM instead of To the Moon.
[list]
[*] The pixel art is fantastic, it gives off so much character.
[*] Gameplay has become a little better since TTM: a more interesting puzzle with increasing difficulty and overall better responsiveness in movement (maybe I just got used to it).
[*] The music is absolutely amazing.
[*] I was afraid the author would start repeating himself, which is not the case. The story is extremely well-crafted, and it effectively represents its themes (which are deeper than TTM's).
[/list]

[i] As great as (if not better than) To the Moon. [/i]

9/10

Builds on what the last game did and tries some new things. If you enjoyed To the Moon, this is an obvious recommendation.

88219591.review:
Another beautiful game from the creators of To The Moon.

Emotional, poignant storytelling that makes you confront your own mortality, while still allowing for some comic relief.

No flaws, other than the player characters' speed, which is a little slow. Somewhat pronounced, given this game is longer than To The Moon.

[b]Advice to those who have not played other games in this series:[/b]

Although the game is self-contained, and it is not required to have played previous games/minisodes in the series beforehand, I recommend that you do so. There are many in-jokes, Easter Eggs and background details that you will not fully appreciate if this is the only game you've played. Without getting into spoilers, it is also fun to see how the formula from To The Moon is played with, and to speculate about the overarching plot running between the games- [i]if[/i] there is one.

87731302.review:
This is a great game. The characters are all enjoyable and the story was built up well. The jokes were funny at times, but the jokes were mostly cringe, in my opinion.

My main complaint is that I didn't cry at the ending. The story didn't resonate with me. Halfway through the story, I lost some interest when the plot twist was revealed. I can't relate to how the main character feels and why he did what he did. I was also hoping the ending would've been different than it was.

Some levels were a little difficult to understand what to do at, but I eventually got it. The puzzles are very simplistic, despite them being more engaging than in the prequel.

The playtime is very, very short. I beat the game in a few hours. I would wait until the game goes on sale for a few dollars because it's not worth $10 to me. The gameplay doesn't offer anything unique that you can't get from just watching a playthrough on YouTube. It's literally point-click, walking around and solving very basic puzzles. The game doesn't even offer any achievements to extend playtime. There is only one achievement, which is awarded upon game completion.

The gameplay is very linear. You don't really make any choices that matter, which is unfortunate. The game would've been more interesting with multiple endings and game-changing choices.

Without getting into too much spoilers, I would still recommend this game for anyone who wants a good story. I know this game makes a lot of people cry, so you probably won't have the same gripes I did about the ending. The journey is amazing. Just wait for it to go on sale.

86765709.review: This game is something else. You will love it, it will make you cry (most likely, several times), but that's not actually what makes it as amazing as it is. It's the emotional depth, the profound message it carries, the way it drives you to understand a complex emotion and how to manage it. Something that requires to actually comprehend deep emotional and philosophical truths in order to be made, and told in an astounding way too. I played it in one sitting, and then spent nearly three hours thinking about it, realizing that many small details throughout the game actually contained deeper messages, that could only be grasped after seeing the full story. This is a game that clearly took a lot of effort. I had nitpicks while playing it; things I didn't quite like, or which I thought took you too much out of the story, or were too goofy, or too repetitive or gimmicky. However, none of that remains once you finish the game; instead, you get left with something meaningful, conveyed in a masterful way. Perhaps the game is not perfect, and maybe that makes it even better. Can't wait for the third in the series, and I truly hope that there are more like these afterwards...

86299586.review:
Some games you play for the addictive gameplay loops, and other games you play for the experience.  This game is definitely confined to the latter group but I wouldn't have it any other way.  It's a testament to how beautifully the art, music and especially the writing comes together.  Not many storytellers can grip me so well and make me cry manly tears, but Kan Gao does it.

The other thing I really like about the game is how it covers the whole of the emotional spectrum.  Sure. it's a game about trying to grant the wishes of a dying man, so there's plenty of touching sentimental moments.  But that doesn't mean it can't be downright goofy at times. Or even unsettling you with the feeling that something is off. The fact that it doesn't spoil detract from the storyline shows how much charm there is. 

I really enjoyed my time with the characters and had a smile on my face and tears in my eyes more than a few times.  Play 'To the Moon' and then play this.

85471515.review:
Finding Paradise is an RPG-MAKER walking simulator with a great story, just like To The Moon. I'm usually not a fan of these type of games, but as a whole, these games are all gems. This game has added puzzles and some level of interaction in the game, so it's not just walking thankfully.

First of all, it needs to be said: the music in this game is amazing. The art is pretty cute, but it isn't the strongest point in my opinion. The game tells you a story about an old man seeking one final chance to overcome his regrets and live his "dream", which Sigmund Corp can always provide as it is their job. They send the two heroes, Neil and Dr. Eva. You will take a trip inside Colin's memories, reviving his life as best he recalls and fulfill his final wish.

While the game doesn't give much liberty or choices, the story it tells will take you on a roller-coaster of emotions. Keep in mind this game is half emotional/half comedy and I laughed more than I thought I would. The game didn't bring me to tears, but I felt a connection and was emotive throughout the second-half of the game.

Either way, I recommend Finding Paradise, it is a great game. The price is rather fair, but as always I would suggest to wait for a sale, at least half the price is worth it 100% if you loved To The Moon or this game catches your attention.

85433003.review: Though this game I think was shorter than To The Moon, it still has the rich story telling aspect. It's been 10 years since then and I FreeBird managed to blow me away with another game.

Just finished the game and... good lord. 
A common retort to the argument of "you can judge a game's worth by how much time you spend with it" is "you can spend a lot of time with a short game if it occupies your thoughts long after you put it down." Finding Paradise is the sort of experience where that applies a hundred fold. 
Some games are easily digestable, occupying your time when "big brain thoughts" would do more harm than good. Others, you'll remember for a while - maybe bringing it up with friends when they ask for game recommendations. But a select few games strike a chord, resonating on a much deeper level and finding a home within your soul. I can say with 100% certainty that Finding Paradise is one of those games. Worth the money, worth your time, worth everything. Do not skip this one, it's a real gem.

84861033.review:
After years of owning the game (bought because of the prequel To The Moon), I finally decided to give this game the chance it needed and complete it in one sitting (~6-8hrs).

Firstly, I would advice any potential players to play at least the first game 'To The Moon' first, before this one. That will allow the player to further appreciate the characters and the references to the previous games much more. There is negligible 'gameplay' differences between the games, as the game has very simple controls bar just a few scenes that need a bit more dexterity (but are very doable).

This game for most, would be a single playthrough game, and personally, just like the previous game, it was very worth it. The linear story is presented and told beautifully, whilst still managing to inject humor and mystery without feeling forced. This is a story which will resonate differently to different people, but would be enriching none-the-less. The music is once again, fantastic.

If and when there's more works from the studio, I'll definitely keep my eye out.

Thanks freebird games, for moving my heart.

84654465.review:
[h1]FINDING PARADISE[/h1]

Rating: Very Good
Genre: Story Heavy/Pixel Art/Puzzle
100% Time: 4-6 hours
Quick Summary: Another masterpiece in story telling, Finding Paradise is yet another brilliantly written adventure by Kan Gao. Whether it is as good as To The Moon is subjective, but otherwise it's a must play for people who really care about beautiful stories.

[i]Positives[/i]
[list]
[*] There's nothing much to say about this game when it comes to positives, in a good way. It's entire focus is on story and boy does it deliver. A beautiful journey through the life of a man who has regrets that he doesn't want to change, a family he doesn't want to leave while still feeling like something is missing. No matter your age the story is relatable and there are so many quotes and moments that just really speak to you. As far as story heavy games go, Freebird Games has never disappointed.
[/list]
[i]Negatives[/i]
[list]
[*]There negatives do not at all detract from the story but are still easily noticeable unfortunately. Movement speed is still way too slow, the game has zero options (options menu wise I mean, because there is no options menu, playing in windowed mode on anything higher than 1920x1080 will make you squint and probably go blind, the puzzles are still not fun (although they are better than To The Moon's sliding puzzles) and there is nothing unique or innovative about it's structure as a game. You can tell the only reason to make this story into a game is to get the player involved in the actions and decisions so the story hits heavy and not for any reasons related to gameplay itself.
[/list]

EXTRA: When I finished To The Moon, I was about 22. I cried like a little girl. It was easily one of the best stories I had ever read. I did not cry for Finding Paradise. I did tear up at the very end, but did not cry. Whether this is due to me not finding the story as unique (not that I can even remember the details of To The Moon anymore) or I have gotten older and more apathetic i'm not sure. I'm 28 as of writing this. I still cry watching sad anime moments, but rarely cry at TV shows. I still cry watching video game characters I know and love go through emotional or physical turmoil. I don't particularly care what happens to characters in TV shows. You need to play this game for yourself to find out whether or not this is the kind of story you are into.

But play "A Bird Story" first.

Thoughts while playing: "Oh god please tell me I don't have to backtrack", "HURRY UP", "How long left?", "I'm so sick of these puzzles".

Even if this game didn't hit the same nerve for me as its predecessor, it again offers a great gaming experience. Unfortunately, the music seemed a bit repeated to me and, in comparison, this one was a bit too cheesy to really get me to shed a tear again. All in all, however, it is a nice continuation of the previous story and gives hope for more to come. 84535223.review:
Another beautiful game by Kan Gao. This game is a direct sequel to both To the Moon and A Bird Story, which by the way makes me rethink my view that A Bird Story is a bad game. I would say I recommend it solely for the purpose of enhancing your experience with Finding Paradise. So, let us go for it.

[h1] Story/Characters: 10/10 [/h1]

As in To the Moon, the story is simply well written and well delivered. Another touching, sentimental master piece. Do note that the aspects of both games are entirely different, as the goals of the dying character are entirely different. Fortunately, it delivers an equally good story.

Minor spoilers below:
Colin is a human being. He lived, basically, the best of his life. He married, had a son, lived his dream of being an airplane pilot. He fulfilled almost everything one could wish for in life. But he still feels some void. He still has some empty space on his heart, that he does not understand, and, as his dying wish, he wants to fill that void. But there's a catch: he wants that without any changes to his life, because, as I said, he loved his life. He loved his wife, his kid, his job. He didn't want to lose any of that. So, how to make someone that doesn't feel completely satisfied... feel satisfied without changing anything?

We find out what is the void, and we find out a way, or at least we hope so, to fill it. And in the meantime, as usual, we learn a little bit more about life, about feelings, about insecurities, about everything human. This is the beauty of this game.

Also, [b]it has Rudog[/b].

[hr][/hr]
[h1] Gameplay: 8/10 [/h1]

Same as To the Moon. Fairly simple object-finding scenes and puzzles. As in to the moon, the gameplay is not a way to deliver a challenger, rather, it is a way to deliver the story. In a game where story is the key element, the challenges being easy enough that they don't break the immersion or make you frustrated is, in my opinion, the best thing you can do.

The reason it's not a 10/10 is simply because gameplay isn't the focus of the game, so you can't say it has an incredible gameplay when, being fair, there is so little of it, even though it serves its purpose perfectly.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] Visual Art: 9/10 [/h1]

Kan Gao actually managed to improve some details from To the Moon. The scenery are so beautiful, the character design is charming, the color choices are perfect. The game is simply truly beautiful.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] Soundtrack: 10/10 [/h1]

Oh well, another masterpiece from Kan Gao and Laura Shigihara. Wish my Life Away is one of my favorite video games music, along many other works from Shigi. Important information though: after playing the game, listening to these musics will most likely make you cry. Do it at your own risk.

Finding Paradise doubles down on everything that made this series meaningful and represents a true sequel that succeeds in a special way. There is more gameplay, comedy, and interaction than the series has ever seen. Each detail is carefully crafted to provoke insight that reaches beyond these events in unexpected ways. 

The work that Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts do calls upon many burning questions, some of which are answered through their time spent inside Colin's memories. By the end of this experience, you realise that everything that happened before has only deepened in breadth and scope. It reminds me that through all of the irony of what can change in life, what remains is greater because of that. 

If you are looking for an emotional journey that understands what it means to turn the page, then let the wonder never fade. Game on.

An RPG Maker game has no right to hit this hard.

After a slow first act the game comes into its own and is by far the most emotionally engaging story of the series. I'd personally rank it as one of the most impactful games I've ever played.

Play it (now!) in one sitting.

In short, this is an interactive visual novel where you walk around oldschool JRPG style gathering clues around different memory fragments unlocking what transpired during the protagonist's life.

83870667.review:
I enjoyed To The Moon's story and worldbuilding, despite its flaws in the tedium of basic gameplay mechanics. After Bird Story, which cranked everything tedious up to 11, I was really worried about the direction of the series. But, I was quite pleased with Finding Paradise, which returns to an excellent story and course corrects on the gameplay mechanics. 

There are fewer opportunities to uselessly sidetrack, and several of the options for doing so have a bit of extra optional dialogue that removes the feeling of wasting time by walking down the wrong path. The game makes some incremental progress in the varying the light gameplay that pads out story scenes: for instance, while you still solve quick puzzles before jumping between life scenes, the puzzle mechanics develop throughout the game, mildly reducing the repetition of the scene - puzzle - scene loop. It's not groundbreaking, but a nice iterative improvement.

The most annoying remaining scrap of tedium is your incredibly slow walk speed. Charitably, it's perhaps intended to control the game's pacing, but any benefits of that aren't worth the wasted time. Cynically, it could be meant to pad out the game's playtime for sales purposes. Regardless of why, it ought to be significantly increased so the player can focus on the story, rather than walking down long hallways (of which, at least there are fewer in this chapter). There's a point at the end of the game where, after you've viewed each memory, you're allowed to return to them; the walk speed is approximately doubled in these retreaded scenes, and that ought to be the walk speed for the entire game.

Overall, I'm happy with the iterative improvements, and the story is well written to continue what's been great about the series so far. If you enjoyed or were ambivalent toward To The Moon, this once does the same type of story a bit better.

83284338.review:
I wish there was a "meh" option. Although I do not write too many reviews or even serious ones, I feel I need to write it for this game specifically. It is a decent game but there are too many problems for me with this game to like it. 

[h2]What I liked[/h2]

[list]
    [*] I liked the soundtrack. The "scale theme" is easily one of my favorite pieces in gaming actually, which was a real surprise for me
    [*] Great pixel art graphics. If you like pixel art, then this is a beautiful game.
    [*] Story is all right but not my taste. It had some fun moments, but mostly disappointing for me. I will explain below why, if you are interested. It did set me to think about life a bit, so I can give that some credit, but not more than this. 
[/list]

Sadly, that is all she wrote on the positive side imo.

[h2]What I disliked[/h2]

[list]
    [*] The gameplay feels old, and not in a good way. I feel this games goes back 20 years or more in terms of gameplay. This is definitely not necessary. I think pokemon emerald had much smoother gameplay than Finding Paradise for instance. It is so weird to control. Tried different methods but all were really bad imo. I get that the game does not have to play as fast as emerald, but you can implement a system like in Enter the Gungeon where you walk anywhere you like. That would fit the game much better. 
    [*] Why does this game have puzzles? Like for real, I found this relatively boring most of the time. It slows down the flow of the story imo and is also not necessary. I think the game is better without them, which includes searching for [spoiler] Memory shards/orbs of Colin's life and perparing the new memories. [/spoiler]
    [*] It was made in 2017/2018 and there is still no options menu? For real? I could not find anything in game. Searching the internet for any options is not the way to go. This should be in every game by default, no matter if you are an indie studio or not.
    [*] The hitboxes in this game are also not great. Clicking on certain objects will accidentilly move the character somewhere else. Really dissappointing, since this is imo immersion breaking. 
    [*] What is the use of inventory? There is a character menu, ok. There is an inventory menu, ok. There is a notes menu, ok. But then the developers actually do not do anything with this? I like the notes menu if you have not played a while or you want to examine things more closely, but the rest is obsolete based on my playthrough. This is also true for the character switching mechanic, which was implemented in the first 15 minutes or so and then never used again. Why? 
    [*] I feel the game sets you up to make some decisions during the game, but in the end have no influence on the actual ending. Like why? Why even give the player choice when there is nothing that makes the player's decisions influence the game. It feels as if the develoopers had some great ideas, but did not execute them or forgot about them. The only decision I liked was at the beginning (see next item in list) and that was it.
    [*] Some elements of the story are truly immersion breaking. I think this may be the signature of the developers, but I was not a fan of it. For instance [spoiler] Going KameHameHA or suddenly spawning a certain suit of armor out of nowhwere. [/spoiler] Like, why? I did like some moments, like [spoiler] the guy kicking the girl's doll into the pool was funny and relatable.[/spoiler] but there were too few of them imo, especially near the end of the game.
    [*] Overall, it was a beautiful story, but there are too many elements in them that I cannot relate to or do not understand still. For instance, (Ending spoiler!) [spoiler] the imaginary friend Faye part was so strange to me. And her first going haywire and then calming again, going haywire and eventually becoming a"good" character? What was that all about? [/spoiler]. Moreover, they did try to get the theme of death, regrets and carpe diem across, showing various scenes from the past, but never capitalised on this further. For instance,  [spoiler] He regrets throwing over a lemon juice/coffee or something. But there is no amending this regret of the sort? [/spoiler]. Maybe I expect too much from this game, but I feel they truly set you up to make some important decisions while this is not the case at all. Also, I am not a fan of the theme regrets and themes similar to this, but that is my personal opinion.
[/list]

In short, I found the story a mess, the gameplay extremely clunky, the puzzles boring, parts of the story extremely immersion breaking and the false feeling of making impactful decisions, with a few techincal issues on the side. Therefore, I sadly cannot recommend this game. Buy it if you think it is interesting, because it is cheap after all, but note that I had problems with the above.

82684589.review: Another wonderful story befitting a sequel to "To the Moon". While the game, again, ins't going to win any prizes in the gameplay design contest - it isn't meant to. The story, however, more than makes up for it. Wonderfully written dialogue underpins a brilliantly written story that both asks some big questions, as well as warms the heart. 82674971.review:
I forgot how much this game meant to me until I saw it while browsing through my steam library this evening. I bought it around November of 2018, and ended up playing it to it's entirety the day after my dad passed away that December. After countless hours of crying upon finishing it, it brought me a sense of peace thinking that maybe this was what my father experienced in his final moments, being able to relive his best memories and achieve everything he wished for with his loved ones surrounding him.

Thank you for this experience, seriously. For making me cry puddles of tears in the matter of 5 hours, and for giving me a sense of peace thinking that he passed on the same way Colin did- now sitting at the beautiful, pearly gates in heaven.

82595800.review:
In Finding Paradise you play and swap between two characters, Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts. You work for Sigmund Corp. A company that grants dying wishes. Imagine in your last breath, your biggest regret disappears, your wildest dream realized, your life completely re-lived and re-written, or just partially enough that you can rest in peace. 
It’s time for you to meet your next patient, Colin. What story will you tell?

I am so impressed with Finding Paradise, I went in nearly blind and I was just blown away by the sheer quality. The music was heartfelt, the scenes were stunning, and the story was brilliant! Finding Paradise is actually a sequel of To The Moon, but both stories can be read alone. I also want to mention that this game is definitely meant to be played in one sitting, and takes about 5-6 hours to finish.

80457827.review:
Finding Paradise was an interesting story to walk through, which is probably the best description I can give for it..... There are no real puzzles or gameplay, and you can play the game entirely with your mouse only. The creators had a story and moral they wanted to present, and they did it well, but this genre of game is REALLY only for people who are okay with walking simulators.

There are very, very tiny portions in the very end that involve minigames, but these felt extremely out of place and were there for comedy, so I'll ignore them entirely in this. 

I picked this game up in a Humble Subscription, saw some of my steam friends played it and loved it, saw all the comments saying they cried and found the story deeply impacting..... I had high expectations going into this, and to be honest, I was incredibly underwhelmed throughout most of the game. 

The concept of this world---being able to die and have scientists recreate your memories for you in your final moments, filling any wish you had---is amazing, I love that *concept*. But the overall protagonist here wasn't relatable at all to me, a wealthy boomer who traveled the world as a pilot, met his wife very early on, and was adored by the people in his retirement building..... A guy with a fulfilled life, who still complained that it could have been better, and who's wish was just that: Keep my memories the same but make them better. 

I found him unlikable for the majority of the story, and I found the pacing of the story to be very slow and tedious. In certain portions, the characters move very fast but these portions happen rarely. For the most part, you move at a snail's crawl, and the gameplay is the exact same in every "memory". You walk around, listen to the story progression, get memory orbs for listening, and move on to the next section. That's it for the entire game. I can also safely say that the "plot twist" was extremely predictable and something I had confirmed myself early on in the game. I couldn't even play this game in one sitting because the story dragged on for so long, and I didn't feel pulled in at any point, so these short hours were done over the course of three days. 

However, I know this review sounds like it should be a thumbs down, and perhaps if I never completed it I would have. But it's that damn plot twist---even though it was cliche, even though I saw it coming, even though I was completely annoyed and done with the game by then--- it still brought tears to my eyes. For what it's worth, the plot twist makes the game, and its presentation and dialogue for that section is outstanding. The patient becomes likable and very human in those moments, and I found myself--- someone who wasted my entire life daydreaming-- actually relating to him. 

I wish the entire game had been handled in the way those scenes were, but I understand the creator wanted it to hit hard and to pace the emotion of it. Because of those sections, and genuinely ONLY because of those sections, I can that yes, this game is worth getting. I can only recommend it in bundles or on sale though, 10$ for this type of game would be a ripoff.

80053188.review: Es de mis juegos favoritos, ya quiero que salga la tercera parte, lo recomiendo mucho :3

79783952.review: Another gem from Freebird Games. Although A Bird Story is not as good a game as this, I strongly recommend you play that first before starting Finding Paradise, which follows on from it and makes the whole story that much more effective. If you've played To the Moon, this game is very similar to it mechanically - you still take control of two scientists entering a dying man's mind to fulfil his last wish, you still search each memory to find "mementos" that link his memories together, and there are still some little minigames you play which activate these objects. But the story is a completely new one and focuses on something a lot more grounded in reality I suppose than wanting to go to the Moon. Here your patient's last wish is something a lot of us can relate to, and the reasons for it tug at your emotions that much more as a result. Any of us who have had regrets in our lives and wished for just that small something to be different will understand. There's not much more to be said than this without spoiling it really. It's an interactive story, but one which made me alternately sad and relieved. Try it.

78572774.review:
Un juego hecho con amor y cuya mirada se centra en un toque emocional. En esta historia somos trabajadores para una empresa que es capaz de alterar los recuerdos de las personas antes de morir, cumpliendo así sus fantasías como último deseo; será pues nuestra tarea, encargarnos de un caso muy particular. 

Como siempre, la nota está al final. 

POSITIVO 
->Historia: Simple pero efectiva para lo que se propone. Su énfasis está siempre en el contenido emocional y como tal es una historia que llega a tocar temas sensibles tales como la soledad, el miedo, las fantasías y el amor. 
->Referencias: El juego está repleto de referencias a otros videojuegos, comics, anime/manga, cine y hasta cultura popular. Si llegas a entender las referencias, los comentarios irónicos y las situaciones chuscas, te divertirás como un enano. 
->Música: Excelente, sobre todo en los momentos de tinte emocional más fuerte. 
->Mecánicas sorpresas: Aunque el juego en un 90% se maneja sobre una misma línea, existen pequeñas secciones que son brillantes haciendo referencia a otros géneros (de videojuegos) siendo tanto homenaje como sátira. 
->Duración: Para ser un juego de este tipo tiene una duración aceptable de unas 5 a 6 horas. 

NEGATIVO 
->Elementos desperdiciados: Desde el planteamiento se nos colocan elementos sumamente interesantes que no se profundizan, siendo esto una pena, ya que habrían dado para grandes momentos a modo de secuencias secundarias. 
->Simplicidad: Si bien el juego es bueno, existen algunas secciones que se sienten simples y muy pesadas, siendo aburridas por tramos considerables. 

NOTA: 7.5 / 10 
Un juego que merece una oportunidad, si eres un amante de este tipo sin duda es una compra obligada, teniendo en cuenta que existe una línea que une a todos los títulos del estudio. No obstante, el juego tiene sus bajas considerables y por ende, no llega a ser una obra maestra como otros juegos del estilo.
