78437068.review:
url=www.youtube.com/watch?v=r876cFMkAjA&list=PLIb_a695uFXDvGvb4Y72bKj1gWGJPmoUY
[h1] First Impressions [/h1] 
When I was first looking at Finding Paradise (FP), I was certain I would be in for a grand time. The review score is at a very impressive 97%, with thousands of people giving their opinion. I figured it would be particularly poignant, either pulling at my heart strings or leaving me something to ponder for a while. As I got into FP though, it didn't really deliver for me. Since the story was a significant part of my issue with FP, I will emphasize that throughout the review there will be spoilers about the story.  


[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
Though FP is an RPG maker game, there's no RPG elements such as combat or leveling up. FP is essentially an interactive story, with the gameplay consisting of exploring areas, talking with other characters, and advancing the story. However, the story doesn't advance in a sequential or linear fashion, as you zip back and forth through the dying man's life. I'd contend the game works reasonably well in framing each area you play through and showing the main figures involved. It's almost always clear what you need to do in each section, and you can usually predict what items in the vicinity will have significance.  


[h1] Story [/h1]
I found FP's story to be strange, confusing, and pathetic. You play as a male and female duo working for a company that taps into terminal peoples' minds to fulfill their pre-death fantasies. In this case, you're trying to do this for an older gentleman who keeps stone-walling about what his wish is, saying he doesn't want any changes made to his life, which would defeat the entire point of getting them involved.   

The primary source of regret he has is when he said goodbye to his imaginary friend, spurred on by him getting married and not having time for that anymore. This is beyond bizarre, and hardly seems like a loss, compared to family and friends dying, trauma, etc. As you explore his mind, you see moments in his life he felt some remorse or disappointment in, yet they're so paltry I rolled my eyes at how charmed a life he led. The worst he ever seemed to have it is when he was a lonely kid, but there were no indications he was being bullied or had neglectful, unloving parents. If that's his life at its worst, I'll have what he's having. 

What makes no sense to me is that if he misses his imaginary friend so much, there's nothing prohibiting him from bringing her back. It's his imagination, it's all in his own mind! He's not feeble-minded and senile, so what's stopping him from playing pretend with himself like he used to? He's upsetting his wife with the implication he regrets how his life turned out, all for the sake of a pretend pal? She doesn't believe him when he says how much he loves his family, as his actions speak far louder than his words. “Hey, I love my family with all my heart, I have no regrets... but here's thousands of dollars, grant me one final wish before I die, when I could be spending this time with them instead. Here's the important part. Don't change a thing.” The protagonists read between the lines, why wouldn't his family?


[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
The graphics in FP come from RPG Maker, but they do a serviceable job for a game of this nature, as they put effort into adjusting lighting and using different visual effects for punch. For instance, the developers make good use out of the premise that you're inside a person's memories, as things don't always have to follow the rules of physics or reality. In some situations I feel like they back out of this prematurely, like when you change the doctor's avatars.  


[h1] Sound Design [/h1] 
There's several tracks that play throughout FP, and I really enjoyed the different instrumental music that was composed for the game. The sound effects used were stock RPG maker noises, but again they served their purpose, so I had no problem with that. 


[h1] Pros [/h1] 
🌟 The introductory clip shows the main characters avoiding a squirrel on the road, almost wrecking the car as they barely dodge vehicles carrying hazardous materials. Over the top moments like these show one part of the writing I liked, which was the comedy.  
🌟 Not every character shines, but many of them had strong, interesting personalities. For instance, the two characters you control, as well as Roxanne.  


[h1] Cons [/h1] 
❌ The inclusion of the “mini-game” battles against the antagonist didn't work well. They included more than one forced loss, which just wasted time. It wasn't funny, interesting, or engaging, just a distraction.  
❌ Throughout most of FP, the movement speed of the characters is slow, which doesn't really fit this mindset that they're on a tight time limit. It's only in the late game that you start jogging around.  


[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1] 
At a certain point, I stopped being interested in the story, and simply wanted to get it over with. I think it's because going through a dying man's memories should be significant and potentially painful. Even though he denied any significant regrets, for him to be going through with this, we'd encounter something momentous that occurred. Maybe he was wise enough that he didn't want to blotch out sorrowful moments he experienced, but we'd see them all the same. However, there were never any devastating losses or heart-rending events he went through. At worst, they were goofy or clumsy fumbles in what could have been moments where he looked more cool or eloquent (and in some ways, this may have given him an awkward charm or likability).  

As someone who's lived in the real world, I can't relate to a guy who's gotten everything one could want out of life (satisfying life-long career, good health, and a loving family), and this is the worst he's ever had it. When I started to realize there wasn't going to be a pay-off to this game, the entire story became a farce to me, and I had no empathy for this nut job who had an imaginary friend far beyond the point it made any sense for him to.    

Based on the “woe is me nature” of this story, trying to make waterworks out of a situation where I only shrug my shoulders apathetically, I don't want to play other games in this series to see where the underlying story goes. It's a shame too, because the sense of humor did mesh with my own, and I jived with the characters alright, but I want to engage with stories that have gravity to them. A game that handled this much better, with largely similar gameplay, was Rakuen, of which the music alone is enough to be emotionally stirring. This is because the game's story addresses legitimate loss and grief. I don't recommend FP, because I don't want to sniffle as someone plays the world's smallest violin over non-issues, and I don't see why others would want to either.

It took me several years to finally bring myself to play this game. I bought it when it came out, as To the Moon has been one of my favourite games since I first played it all the way back in 2013, but I was always nervous about starting Finding Paradise up. What if it didn't live up to my expectations? What if it did something to diminish the borderline perfect experience I had with To the Moon?

My fears were unfounded. When I finally made myself sit down and play through Finding Paradise, I quickly realised that it was exactly the sequel it should have been. I don't know what more I can say beyond that: the narrative is different but tonally consistent with To the Moon and every bit as good (if not somehow better), and the soundtrack is everything I wanted it to be. Those are easily the two most important components of To the Moon, so if you liked the first game in the series, there's no reason you won't love this just as much.

Kan Gao has done it again and created another masterpiece. The writing and the music are just so fucking good. The characters, especially Watts, are super charming and amusing. I loved this game so much. It could be recency bias, but I think I may have loved this game even more than To The Moon. I found the plot in Finding Paradise is to be even more intriguing than To the Moon’s. To The Moon was very explicit, even in the title, about the patient’s final wish, but in Finding Paradise, Colin’s final wish isn’t immediately clear and creates this sense of mystery throughout the whole plot of the game as you try to unravel just what about his life he could want to change. It’s fantastic.

The music. Kan is so fucking good. I think Kan’s music is what makes Freebird’s games so amazing. The writing is fantastic, but his music really makes his games feel like something truly special. The standout tracks for me were [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H_TGTDcZe3s]Time is a Place (Piano Version)[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bLkouR1Njgg&list=OLAK5uy_lqVvwS5_ct_n7HJfvxNl2_tDKf1fhCYgg&index=54]Faye’s Theme (Piano Version)[/url].

I’m really looking forward to his next game, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1182620/Impostor_Factory/]Impostor Factory[/url]. Although, I do have to say, I wished something other than RPG Maker was used. I’m not a developer, so I can’t say how RPG Maker is compared to something like Unity, but I just hate the resolution being limited to a 4:3 640x480, and I hate that the Steam overlay doesn’t work with RPG Maker games. Those are just minor peeves of mine. Regardless, Kan has definitely earned an “insta-buy” from me for any future Freebird titles. He hasn’t let me down yet.

76836287.review:
I loved this game!
I'm going to judge this game based on two factors:

1) As a sequel of To The Moon
2) On it's Own Merit

-----
1) For those of you who are not aware, this is the sequel to a previous title called "To The Moon" (and a short entry called A Bird's Story). I HIGHLY recommend you play To The Moon (and maybe A Bird Story) first before you jump into Finding Paradise. In To The Moon, they explain a lot of background about how things generally work in this universe. I would argue that Finding Paradise is meant for those that have already played To The Moon because Finding Paradise makes a lot of blatant AND subtle references to the prequel. The characters jumped straight into the action a bit faster since it's built of the knowledge that the player probably already knows about how the world works. Highly recommend you play that 1st. (As for A Bird's Story, it's more of a short segment, and while there is a few references to that, I don't think it's as important as To The Moon. You could probably skip that if you really wanted to).

Anyway, I do personally believe Finding Paradise is great in terms of keeping up with the lore from the previous title. It also improves on a few things! The artwork was phenomenal, and the animations were never boring to look at. The dialogue was still witty, and clever in certain areas. The music quality is still pretty good. 
Now, in all honesty, I believe To The Moon was a better game than Finding Paradise. The story in To The Moon was a lot more in-depth, and the music was perfect for every moment. In Finding Paradise, I believe it felt a bit short on the clever side. It was there, sure, but it wasn't nearly as in-depth as much as To The Moon. Most of the Notes you find in this game don't really add up to much. Meanwhile, in To The Moon, your Notes would constantly change as you discovered more and more. Here, they don't really do that... Another thing I want to talk about is the movements. In Finding Paradise, you are suuuuper slow in some segments where it really shouldn't be. At least when you were slow in To The Moon, the areas were a lot more confined and such. But in Finding Paradise, the areas tend to be bigger, and more open. It's a bit of a hassle sometimes. The music quality is still good like I mentioned above, but I still feel like the soundtrack for Finding Paradise doesn't amount to To The Moon. However, Finding Paradise is still a good sequel!

2) On it's own Merit, Finding Paradise is excellent! There's some subtle hints and plot twists at unexpected segments. An entirely new concept arises, and is explored pretty thoughtfully. The main characters are perfect duos for the main player to play as, and the plot of the story is overall just...well thought-out. The game is still in the realm of "book/visual novel that you manually make progress in", so if that's not your thing, you probably won't like it. But still, it's definitely a pretty good in terms of story and cutscenes. It's still a thought-provoking experience and it's something I still believe everyone should try at least once in their lives.

------

Overall, I believe To The Moon was better than Finding Paradise, but Finding Paradise is still pretty darn good! You should definitely play this if you are a fan of To The Moon!

76550679.review:
Finding Paradise is an indie game made by a handful of people - and I will judge it as such.

First of all the graphics are pretty simplistics.
Early-mid 90s style top-down 2D graphics.
What is called 8-bit graphics.

The controls are pretty simple too - You have the Up,Down,Left,Right buttons, and the action button. Or a mouse can be used instead.
Even though the Steam overlay says it only support Keyborad/Mouse, a controller will work pretty well too.

The game is relatively bug-free.
There were some minor glitches in the mini-games (like enemy projectiles not harming you), but I'm not entirely sure if they weren't intentional.

Ok so now that we've covered all the side stuff, lets get to the gist of it.
How does a small indie game, with unremarkable controls, graphics and gameplay gets 97% positive rating on Steam with 8,500+ reviews?
By having a great story and an amazing soundtrack, that's how.

The store in the game is really great.
It's actually a sequel to "To the Moon", but you don't really miss much by not playing the previous game.
The beginning of the game is spent on various side-stories, which help in building the background and general atmosphere of the game.
And as the game progresses, the main story picks up and pulls you in.
The soundtrack is amazing as well - surprising for a game of this caliber.

Now I'm not going to lie that this game has the best story, plot or dialog I've seen in a PC game.
But it's god damn good.
Especially considering how small the group of people that made the game was.

76197541.review:
[b]Genre:[/b] Adventure, Puzzle
[b]Playtime:[/b] 4-5 hrs
[b]Rating:[/b] 85/100
[b]Content Warnings:[/b] Themes of death, a few problematic comments about mental health issues
[b]Review:[/b]
Finding Paradise is a fun little narrative-heavy adventure game about a pair of scientists trying to fulfil a dying man's wishes by exploring his memories inside a virtual environment. It starts as a simple stroll back through time, but things inevitably get a bit strange. What is the mysterious entity interrupting your work? Will you find out before it's too late?
I enjoyed this game quite a bit. It was a touching story all-in-all, although some of the writing was a bit cheesy and immersion breaking at times. (Partially, that's because the person who designed the machine you use is a [i]gamerrrr[/i] and the devs [i]really[/i] want you to know that) The art style is wonderful, especially in some of the "cutscene" sections, and the environments are beautifully done. The music is great, and fits the mood and environment perfectly. Some of the controls were awkward at times, leading me to constantly interact with the wrong thing. I felt it could have been a slightly shorter experience without sacrificing story elements (but I was also tired at the time, so that might have been the issue). Overall, I would recommend this game for its well-done story about realizing that the regrets in your life help you to value the good things.

76180331.review:
This game is in my favorites section.

Finding Paradise, while being able to stand on its own as a complete story, is still the sequel to To the Moon and thus should be played after To the Moon. 

This game is not an action game and there is no RPG combat whatsoever, even though it is indeed a RPGMaker game. This game is more like a visual novel with some simple puzzling, so do not buy it if you're looking for a JRPG type adventure.

75878403.review:
[h1]A Little Bit Too Long Review[/h1]

[quote=Kan R. Gao]To the Moon was about seeking fantasy from reality, whereas Finding Paradise is about seeking reality from fantasy. Two sides of the same coin.[/quote]


Finding Paradise is a very special and personal game for me. For about two years I have been putting it off for later. I regret this decision. Now I want to clear my memory to experience this magical game again. When I first saw the trailer of Finding Paradise I thought that they were gonna create a copy of To The Moon just to repeat it’s success. I was wrong. I was completely wrong. Finding Paradise is a totally different story in the same setting. And it may not be clear at the first launch. 


[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
If you played and liked To The Moon, Finding Paradise is a good game for you. If it is your first game of the Freebirdgames series - it’s OK. All their To The Moon games are a part of a big picture but they are completely standalone at the same time. 

[u]The text below may contain spoilers.[/u]



[h2]To The Moon series template[/h2]
Finding Paradise, as well as To The Moon, uses the same plot structure and methods.

There is the same 3 act structure: intro and first dive, some break out of the machine and secret disclosure, denouement and ending. It also shows you all main character life at the end through complication of his memories with Laura Shigihara song. There is a lot of self citing and self references. Also, some part of the soundtrack is just a cover or copy of the To The Moon soundtrack.

You may be confused for the first 30 minutes. Is this game just a washy copy of To The Moon? No. You are completely wrong. Some people were really confused because of this, and I am not exception. Also, the fact that the plot is slow-paced does not help at all. Sometimes you may need to be a little bit more patient with the game.

Although the game uses the same template and cites a lot it’s prequel doesn’t mean unoriginality. Kan Gao repeats himself with the game structure but not with it’s interior. Actually, the game is filled with a completely different mood and atmosphere than To The Moon.



[h2]Spiral Plot[/h2]
In To The Moon you go through the story backwards but in Finding Paradise they follow spiral structure. You will jump from latest protagonist memory to earliest again and again, reaching some center, some important life changing moment.

I found this idea very accurate for this story. You observe two parallel stories about the same man.  In To The Moon we were wondering, what are prerequisites of this time point, whilst in Finding Paradise we are trying to make a connecting between two time separated man conditions and guessing what is a crucial moment.



[h2]Soundtrack and Atmosphere[/h2]
I dare say that Kan Gao is a genius of video game music. He creates such heartbreaking songs even for common and trivial scenes that it makes you stop and listen for the end. Soundtrack is a core part of the To The Moon series and Finding Paradise is not an exception. It is still the strongest component of the game. It is a central part of the game atmosphere. Placing the right song in the right moment Kan Gao makes you immersed with the character's life. Do not be cheap and get OST with the game. It will make your life better.



[h2]Ending and Message[/h2]
As the epigraph said, To The Moon was about hiding in illusions and fantasies. The protagonist was ready to rewrite his entire life. Finding paradise is vice versa. It raises an important topic of self acceptance. It is about overcoming the temptation and understanding of your true happiness. Finding Paradise demonstrates the importance of the ability to appreciate what you have and not trade it for anything. It is a very powerful message.



[h2]P.S.:[/h2]
I actually found there are a bunch of people that didn’t get the ending. I was wondering could they not get it if it was noted in plain text in the game:
[list]
[*][spoiler]Colin explains it at one of the first meetings with him.[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]Faye explains it multiple times.[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]Niel explains it at the ending.[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]Colin explains it again in the final balcony scene.[/spoiler]
[/list]

75117010.review:
[i]'The man who has no imagination has no wings' - Muhammad Ali[/i]

[b]Freebird's[/b] second title in the [u]To the Moon[/u] series takes itself less seriously yet still manages to deliver a heartfelt story full of melancholy inbetween its humorous dialogue.  This time around the emotional story is equally balanced with ample easter eggs of countless references to popular games both past & present that you wonder where they all are coming from until the finale is unleashed concerning Sigmund's latest client, Colin, and his mysterious past with Faye. 

[i]Finding Paradise[/i] offers similar puzzles featured in [i]To the Moon[/i] where you manipulate rows & columns to 'match 3' to unlock the assigned memory item and, considering my playtime of [b]yikes[/b] 7-8 hours, you'd think the puzzles are challenging (well, they are as the game progresses hah!) but the reason my playtime is so high is due to a battle tribute to [u]Dr Watts[/u] obsession with games like [i]Dragon Ball Z[/i] so yeah... major fail!!!

Sooo...back to [i]Finding Paradise[/i] where, at the early stages of the game, I must admit to be being distraught at the direction it was taking with what appeared to be familiar territory of Dr Watts & Dr Rosalene journeying to a new client in order to fulfill their dying wishes; all good so far with keeping in tune to its predecessor yet I kept seeing emphasis on the humour and a slow build on the client, Colin and his journey.  I found the memories of Colin to be almost mirroring scenes from [i]To the Moon[/i] very early on but, to my relief, there were some unique sequences as the story transposes to Act II and it developed its own identity.

One scene that stood out for me was the aquarium setting because, considering Freebird Games make use of RPGMaker XP, they still attain highly detailed pixel graphics that make that event feel alive on your screen with its vibrant use of colours and animated sequences. I don't think I was the only one who enjoyed that particular part of the game.. a certain Dr seemed to appreciate its wonders too!!
There are ample animated scenes to portray the story giving it a cinematic vibe while also providing a brief respite between the puzzles and mysterious, slow-paced memory trail of Colin's past. This could frustrate some players who purely want to control the game at their pace yet patience is needed throughout the cut-scenes as they have a purpose to the story.

The controls are simple to adapt to even when Freebird Games provide on-screen reminders they are purely aesthetical as any player will be picking up the buttons with ease.  The menu is accessible anytime throughout the game allowing you to save at leisure in a header-tabbed screen that is manipulated with the arrow keys.  
The OST is perfectly set to elevate the tone of the story and the song finale sung by [i]Laura Shigihara[/i] entitled [b]wish my life away[/b] is very touching and emotional.  All subtle clues to Colin's back story with Faye.

Overall, the journey throughout this game managed to deliver its feels alongside an intriguing twist all while ebbing us along with its superb humour & delicate emotional reveals.  The puzzles are a good mix of logic that aren't too difficult while the battles are all based upon timing and attack tactics.
If you previously played [b]To the Moon[/b] or [i]A Bird's Story[/i] and adored them you are guaranteed a memorable ride with [u]Finding Paradise[/u] too.

~~~ Liked what you see? You can find more reviews at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32839633]Have a Word[/url]~~~

75045010.review:
This game feels like it was written by a pair of 15 year olds. The dialogue just feels off, like in a Joe Biden "no malarkey" sort of way. I knew it was some Asian American millenial behind it, that world is all too familiar with me, and hey, turns out I was right. It was written by an Asian guy when he was at most 20 (and TTM was written when he was 16). 

"Finding Paradise" wants to be cool, in too many ways for it to matter in any of them. Poignant, with its music and premise, funny, with its levity and humor, clever, with it's twist and moral pearl. It is none of these things. It is pretentious, unfunny, and unimpressive. It thinks it can just string together the right cliches, the right story beats, but it feels too artificial, too by-the-numbers -- as if Kan Gao, its writer and musician, went directly to writing it after watching a youtube course on storytelling uploaded by someone in 2013. It makes for a flat experience, one that keeps you hoping that the game really is just all bad so it's easier to write it off as trash. 

The real sin of this game isn't that it's horrible. It's that it's boring.

At first, I've written in this review that in terms of emotional impact, I preferred "To The Moon." However, I soon realized (after watching a streamer play the game) that I shouldn't compare the two games. Each installment has its own unique theme; and of course, everyone's experience with the games would be different. It was refreshing to see the game in another person's perspective, as well as its impact on them. Thus, I think that "Finding Paradise" was an emotional rollercoaster filled with laughs and tears. It actually makes you reflect deeply on your life... especially if you had regrets, too. I found that it was something that I appreciated even more on a "second playthrough." [i]although technically I just watched the run haha[/i] 
Apart from this, the soundtrack was amazing as always! The storytelling was brilliant and enjoyable, as well. I was very invested in the 'subplot' involving Neil Watts and a couple others... Finding Paradise es el segundo capitulo de la indie Freebird que continua la historia de los protagonistas de la primera entrega y que se enfrentan a un nuevo desafío. Sigue el mismo tono que su predecesor con una "charla" filosófica de que uno puede decidir "organizar" su historia de su vida de tal manera de que pueda dejar este mundo habiendo sido feliz. Se trata de un juego que se basa en la narrativa y en el contenido emocional.

PROS
- A pesar de que es la segunda parte, no deja nada que envidiar a la la primera entrega To The Moon
- Gráficos retro
- Historia muy absorbente, una vez la empiezas, la querrás acabar
- Muy emotiva
- Contenido musical del autor, muy cautivador y acompaña perfectamente durante todo el videojuego

CONTRA
- Muy corto (unas 4-5 horas), dado su contenido narrativo, lo veo correcto
- Sin dificultad, salvo de unos pequeños rompecabezas que se deben realizar para "pasar" de nivel

Se trata de un juego indispensable para poder gozar junto a su preciosa banda sonora. Evitar si lo que buscáis es acción.

After having played "To the Moon" I was doubtful that any game would come close, let alone equal the emotional depth of that masterpiece. I was hesitant to play this game as I didn't want the continuation of the main characters in TtM to be a letdown, but it wasn't.

The 10/10 soundtrack (which in my opinion may top that of TtM, even though TtM has some amazing songs) added with Kan Gao's wonderful storytelling left another mark on me that I will cherish for years to come. I cannot express how great these games are, you just have to play them yourself. 

I am beyond happy to hear that there will be a third game in this series released at the end of 2020.

72584109.review:
Another FreeBird game! Better get some protection on those floorboards to avoid water damage from the tears you'll probably be squirting!

Ken Gaos writing is, dare I say, genious. There is an absolute wealth of philosophical & psychological knowledge & insights in these games!
If you haven't played any of his games before you'd be forgiven to think they're mostly downers by all the reaction videos of gamers basically curling into shivering fetal position balls crying their eyes out, getting all red faced & snot threads dangling down onto the keyboards.
They're not *just* that. They're complex, emotional evocative but compelling. They are also self aware and contains some genuinly laugh out loud (or at least snickering) humour. They all avoid the trap of becoming pretentious, which many media forms that tackle deep human questions fall into.

You may also think they are only there to provoke reactions out of you, and yes, to a degree, like all media and entertainment. They manage to never feel cheap though, because they are so expertly crafted and written, with their highly emotive pixel art and fantastic score, and stories that matter, have real weight to them, and that most people can connect to, in some way or other.

I personally was more moved by To the Moon, and even A Bird Story from what I recall, but this title has more  actual gameplay (which was one of the complaints of the earlier titles in the series) and more elaborate settings and backgrounds. I found it to be a bit of a slow burner but it does take off eventually.

I can't say too much because of risk of spoilers, even though I just wanna bombard everyone with quotes from it, so I'll just leave it here.

72553158.review:
12.7.2020.									Game #145

[h1] No game has ever made me cry. This one was dangerously close [/h1]

I’ll say it before and I’ll say it again: I love that I have decided to play all my Steam games in order. If I hadn’t, I never would have played games like “Finding Paradise”. One look at this game is all it takes to make me roll my eyes given that it was made in RPG maker. I said it in one of my last reviews that whenever a game is made in RPG Maker, the best thing it can do to stand out is, ironically, not be an RPG. Not only is Finding Paradise not an RPG, but it’s also [h3] one of the sweetest and most beautiful stories I have ever heard in a video game.[/h3] 

[h1] Making his last wish come true [/h1]

The game starts you off without a warning as Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene as they make their way to a retirement home. A man named Collin Reeds is at his deathbed and the two doctors are there to make his final wish come true. How do they do that? By jacking themselves into his memory using a machine and altering it so that he may experience things he had missed out on or forget his past mistakes that might haunt him. While it may sound strange, the company Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene work for has been around for a while and have served quite a few clients and this sort of request is nothing new to them. However, Collin is a special case. What makes him a special case is that Collin hasn’t properly explained what his final wish was. He wished for the doctors to make him feel like he had lead a fulfilling life but without changing anything. What makes this thing even more interesting is the fact that Collin seems to have lead a very healthy and happy life. He used to be a pilot, money was never an issue, he married a wonderful woman, they were in love and they had a son, so what could Collin possible want to make his life more fulfilling? Well… if I told you that, I’d be a real spoil-sport, wouldn’t I? Let’s just say… it’s about a girl and NO, it's not what you are thinking.

[h1] Collect memories, find mementos and figure things out [/h1]

The game is played as you switch between the two doctors who make their way through the memories of Collin. They usually walk around during his key memories and interact with things around him and listen through the dialogues he has with people from his past. These interactions create memories and upon collecting all of them, they need to bring them to a memento which they use to travel further. It’s kind of like Assassin’s Creed https://store.steampowered.com/app/15100/Assassins_Creed_Directors_Cut_Edition/ meets that movie “The Cell” with Jennifer Lopez (anyone remember that one?).  
Under normal circumstances, the doctors should have been able to travel from Collin’s most recent memory back to his less recent memories but, for some reason, they travel between Collin’s oldest to newest memories. In one Memory they watch him being an old man while in another he is a child and what they really need is something that happened right in the middle of his life. 

[h1] A heart-warming story full of wonderful, relatable, tear-inducing and quirky moments [/h1]

I’ll just say it: Collin had an interesting life. You will get to experience things from his past like his most proud and his most embarrassing moments and they are all done really well. It’s actually pretty amazing what the developer was able to do in just RPG maker. While normally, RPG maker characters are stiff and a bit lifeless, here characters have some unique animations and movements that make them seem more alive and real. It’s still an RPG maker game, so don’t expect to be blown away, but it’s the liveliest one I’ve ever seen. The two doctors that travel through Collin’s memories are also a joy to play as. Dr. Rosalene is a very empathetic and loving person who likes to do things by the book and Dr. Watts is a nerdy scientist who tells terrible jokes and likes video games and anime a bit too much while also being a genius at his work. The two of them, while very different people, make a great team. They will often comment on the situation, making fun of the characters they meet, and just goof off sometimes. 

[h1] Not much gameplay but not too little either [/h1]

It shouldn't come as a surprise that this is a very linear game. You do have some choices to make but they don't really make any differences. While most of the time you will only be walking and talking to characters and interacting with the environment, sometimes you will also get to play a few mini-games. In order to progress through each memory, you have to solve a very simple match 3(or more) puzzle game that usually lasts only a couple of seconds. A few times during the game, you will also get to play a simple mini game (a fighting game, space shooter and even an RPG) and again, these are over just as they begin. It’s a nice change of pace when these occur and they never last long to distract you from the actual plot.

[h1] Wait! There are more of these games? [/h1]

 I was actually blown away at the very end when I found out that this was actually the third game in the series because at no point did it seem like the game was a sequel. I’m happy I’ve got two previous games to look forward to. The first game seems to be To the Moon https://store.steampowered.com/app/206440/To_the_Moon/ and I am very much looking forward to playing this one sometime in the future.

[h1] The music was amazing [/h1]

They really went the extra mile with the music in this game. The music, as well as all the little animations and effects, really made me feel all tingly inside. During key moments the game will just start playing lovely piano and cello melodies to really hammer in the emotions and they work wonders in enchanting the experience even more. There is even a full original song at the end.

[h1] A nasty crash at the very end of the game [/h1]

During the credits, just as I was waiting for the epilogue, the game, not only crashed, but exited Steam as well. At first, I thought it was one of those Undertale https://store.steampowered.com/app/391540/Undertale/ moments, where the game was toying with me but no, it was just a really nasty game crash. It only happened once so, it wasn’t such a big deal. 

[h1] Who would have thought that I would love an RPG maker game so much [/h1]

It really goes to show how amazing video games can be. On one hand, you have these huge, graphically impressive games that, most of the time, make me yawn and then you’ve got humble indie games like Finding Paradise that almost made me cry like a little child. Maybe I’m just becoming a big ol’ softy.

Either way, while the price might be a little high for an RPG maker game and while the game is short enough for a single play session, I wholeheartedly recommend playing Paradise Lost. It was such a sweet story full of love and tenderness that I won’t soon forget and I think you won’t either if you give this wonderful game a chance.

Next game:
Fluffy Horde
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/777880?snr=1_5_9__402

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I’m trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG [/h3]

72063616.review:
TDLR: So anyways, I grabbed a box of tissues and started crying.

If it had not been for the witty humour of Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene to cheer me up here and there, then I would have probably cried harder.  I have played it for 5 hours non-stop and I have finished roughly at 2am in absolute tears. Combined with the music that compliments the scenes, it becomes very emotional. You should definitely get this game, but be prepared with a box of tissues. You will find yourself thinking back to your own decisions you have made in life, asking yourself 'what-ifs'. This game gives you some life lessons through a beautiful story. It has taught me so much, I truly think you'll enjoy it.

[spoiler] Like some reviews that I have seen on here, I too, have been going through something. Playing this game, in a way,  gives me a bit of closure. The eloquent story writing this game has, moved me. This game may not have the realistic graphics like most games now a days, but do not let that put you off. 

 For those that do not know, (I'll try my best to explain since I did find it confusing at first) you play as two doctors, Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene, who work at Sigmund Corporation, a company that helps to 'fulfil one's dying wishes' by altering their memories through a machine. Despite living a happy life, the dying wish of Colin is to have lived the best life he could (like most of us want to do). However he also mentions not to drastically alter his memories, which is quite contradicting, since how would you better your life without changing it much?

As the player/ reader, we can relate to Colin's situation. No matter how happy we are, we always think of the 'what-ifs' of decisions that could possibly making our lives better. We have our regrets when we think back to the actions we make and we really do ask ourselves 'did I make the right choice?' 'would it have been better if i did this?'.

 The game offers a solution to the 'is the grass greener?' thought.  In the end, one of the doctors realises that Colin really did live the most fulfilling life he ever could, however the only thing that was stopping him from feeling like he did, was the thought of a machine that could make it better. The answer was to remove the memory of him ever finding out about the Sigmund corporation and the machine, and therefore he would have lived his life happily without any doubts. Rather than the doctors doing this, they entrust this decision with Colin's imaginary friend Faye (Colin created her out of loneliness), who at first seems to be the antagonist, only because she felt threatened that she would be wiped from Colin's memories. 

The specific interaction between Faye and Colin during the time she decides to leave him is will give you tears (there will be more though).  Like Colin we have to accept that as we get older, we have to let go of our imaginations and let reality kick in so we can be taken seriously and live life how it is (similarly Faye lets go of Colin which he accepts, because she explains that he will be laughed at if people found out he had an imaginary friend and also the fact that they had drifted apart since reality had made him busy). 

The bittersweet farewell between Faye and Colin as an old man, where they face each other on the balcony, is probably the most touching scene. Colin acknowledges his many regrets, but is still happy with the life he has. One of Colin's major regrets though, is that he wished he could see Faye again. He finally got his wish, therefore he could die peacefully.   We may live our lives as happy as we can, however, regrets really can't be avoided. We should be grateful for what we have, and try not to linger on 'what-ifs'. Also just wanted to ask, did you guys reveal to Asher or Sofia about Faye when we thought she was his childhood sweetheart? I said no to give him privacy. [/spoiler]

This game has given me the answers I have needed. Hopefully it will help you too, whoever is reading this. Like Colin, I hope we all can acknowledge our regrets, move on and be grateful for the memories and the life we live. 

Its 4:30 am I probably went off on a tangent and got a little emooshh. can i just say when Watts YEEETS that doll in the pond tho?  aight imma head to sleep reeeeeeee

71191169.review:
Thanks for the male tears game, I appreciate it.

But jokes aside, this game can run on every device, and it's story made me feel engaged with the characters, and how they develop throughout the entire game (a 5 hour game btw) more than 95% of the AAA titles that I've played. 
This game is a must play to everyone that wants one of the best storytellings on a videogame.
Some say they didn't feel the same as with to the moon, but I guarantee you, that's like 10% of the people because I felt 10 times worse at the end. (I watched youtubers and streamers watch the end and cry like a b*tch. I even cried with them, fuck).
One of it's downsides is that it's not long enough for some people, which is a valid argument, but at the same time is a too-good-to-be-true game, so come on, it's not a 50 hour long JRPG, is just a basic gameplay game made with RPGmaker.
The only thing that I didn't like were the tanky controlls, which it doesn't feel that good and the optimization it's pretty rare, sometimes it runs stable but in a few menus the game starts to run at 20fps.

But overall this is a 9,5/10 to me, because the story is everything that counts in this kinds of game, and the gameplay doesn't matter, you're not here just to collect mementos, are you?

70589955.review:
Finding Paradise is a compelling, mature, and deeply philosophical story, if somewhat cheesy... but true to life and true to the world. Regret being the topic, it surely touches everyone. The game is very much the same quality in crafting and meaningfulness as To the Moon was. If you loved To the Moon as I did, you’ll surely like Finding Paradise. I’ll admit a tear or two rolled down my cheek while playing, especially in the [spoiler]hospital scene…[/spoiler] That is quite unique coming from a video game, and to be able to do that twice in a row is a statement of narrative expertise. I’ll gladly buy any game these guys conjure up next.

On the downside, gameplay (and the “interactivity” of the story) is very linear, almost nonexistent, although I could see that in adding the minigames, they tried. You’ll feel you are taking a ride in a rollercoaster, instead of driving your own car. This results in not very active gameplay, and I can see this frustrating the active type of players. The story’s format is still hugely better than visual novels, which are not my cup of tea. I did have some technical issues with the game as well, most importantly chat dialogs where choices could be made, did not always appear and I had to choose blindly. I’ll also admit I’m not a big fan of the graphics, but as the story progresses you completely forget them as the story becomes the pearl of the game.

As in To the Moon, the soundtrack of Finding Paradise is marvelous, although not quite as mesmerizing. I did not enjoy the theme song with sung lyrics, and I feel bad about it, but the song felt too childish. All in all, the game is a very well weaved bedtime story and a lullaby.

70044221.review:
Finding Paradise didn't work for me. I played To The Moon years ago and i can't remember if i gave it a good or bad review, but i do remember thinking at the time that it was a pretty unique gaming experience despite the tedious fetch quest mechanics and weirdly shoehorned console gaming jokes. The bad news is that in the years since, loads more excellent "crying games" have come out - RPG Maker games like this one, VNs, walking sims, narrative adventures... so a straight-up sequel isn't going to feel as unique.

The best thing about this game for me is it picks up a thread from A Bird Story, which is by far my favorite game from this developer and the only one that i would still recommend playing today. The unfortunate thing is that Finding Paradise takes A Bird Story and then undermines it by twisting the message into some kind of moralistic teaching on how people should live their adult lives. I am being deliberately vague so as not to spoil a key plot point, but I can say from about halfway through Act 1 it's clear what the Act 2 reveal is going to be, and pretty much all of Act 3 is the opposite of how i had hoped it would've been dealt with.

One ray of light comes in the after credits scene, which teases a move into a potentially more sinister story line. Normally i am not a fan of edgy spin-offs, but in this case it might be just the twist the series needs to make it feel fresh again. I dunno, perhaps my heart just got colder. This one just wasn't really worth the 4 hours, in my opinion.

69831915.review:
Finding Paradise is a RPG maker story game and the sequel to To the Moon continuing the adventures of the doctors Neil Watts and Eva Rosalene to fulfill the last wish of another dying patient. You can expect the usual silliness of Neil and the more serious approach from Eva as they manage to do their job. While the story is great and well presented, To the Moon had a stronger emotional impact.

The graphics are beautiful for a RPG maker game standards and there are nice songs by Laura Shigihara. The gameplay is quite minimal and mostly serves as a way to proceed the story with a few puzzles and mini games. 

For achievement hunters:
One achievement for completing the game.

69807443.review: Great story. This is the first game I have played by these developers, and I didn't have any problems jumping in on this without experiencing To the Moon first. If anything, I feel obliged to go and try that game now as well.

69770454.review:
I love To the Moon. It is without question one of my favouite stories in videogames and even holds it's own when comparing it to my favorite films. Finding Paradise didn't quite make it to the levels of To the Moon for me, but honestly the bar is set so incredibly high that saying that doesn't mean much. While To The Moon has an overall tighter story and is in my opinion better on a literal level, Finding Paradise feels like it holds more of a meaningful message overall, and (I'm trying to keep it vague to avoid spoilers) is more impactful in some areas because of its relatability.

 That being said there was a bit of filler here, although I enjoyed the novelty of some of the minigames, I think I would have preferred a more straightforward experience, as especially on repeat playthroughs I can see myself growing tired of them. If you enjoyed the first game even just a little though, I still think Finding Paradise is more than worth the $10 asking price, and I'll continue to buy anything that Kan Gao and Freebird Games comes out with in the future. Especially if there's an attached Laura Shigihara soundtrack.

69740018.review:
The very first game I played was 'To the moon' and I was pretty excited to see the sequel. Although the first one moved me deeply and got me in to gaming I didn't expect to be completely captivated by "Finding Paradise" as Sequels often aren't. I have recommended 'To the Moon' to many first time gamers (Noobs such as myself) and folks who appreciate story telling in a game.  
Let me just say Finding Paradise is even better, I think both stories complement each other so wonderfully. While 'To the Moon' sets the back drop to the Memory Mechanics and nitty gritties of how it all works  'Finding Paradise' plot thickens in narrative and depth.
This emotionally binding story spoke to me, as it waded through the raw realities of dissatisfaction, plateau, loneliness, regret and through it all how life shapes itself in to... well.. paradise.
  "I think all our memories, and everything in it... can be nothing but the fiction we tell ourselves."

I cannot wait for Episode 3 and the kind of story it would unravel, There was a six year wait between the two games, but I suppose a masterpiece was not built in a day ~ (Y) Kan Gao and the team.
